editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: With the humours of Sir Iohn Falſtaffe▪ As alſo the ſwaggering vaine of Ancient Piſtoll, and Corporall Nym.
LONDON: Printed by T. H. for R. Meighen, and are to be ſold at his Shop, next to the Middle-Temple Gate, and in S. Dunſtans Church-yard in Fleet-ſtreet, 1630.

div.head: Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Iuſtice Shallow, Slender, Sir Hugh Euans, Maſter Page, Falſtoffe, Bardolph, Nym, Piſtoll, Anne Page, Miſtreſſe Ford, Miſtreſſe Page, Simple.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: SIr Hugh, perſwade mee not: I will make a Star-Chamber matter of it, if he were twenty Sir Iohn Falſtoffe, hee ſhall not abuſe Robert Shadow Eſquire.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: In the County of Gloceſter, Iuſtice of Peace and Coram.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I (Coſen Slender) and Cuſt▪ alorum.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I, and Rotulorum too; and a Gentleman borne (Maſter Parſon) who writes himſelfe Armigero, in any Bill, Warrant, Quittance, or Obligation, Armigero.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I that I doe, and haue done any time theſe three hundred yeeres.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: All his ſucceſſors (gone before him) hath don't: and all his Anceſtors (that come after him) may: they may giue the dozen white Luces in their Coate.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: It is an olde Coate.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: The dozen white Lowſes doe become an olde Coat well: it agrees well paſſant: It is a familiar beaſt to man, and ſignifies Loue.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: The Luſe is the freſh-fiſh, the ſalt-fiſh is an old Coate.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I may quarter (Coz).

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: You may, by marrying.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Not a whit.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Yes per-lady: if hee ha's a quarter of your coate, there is but three Shirts for your ſelfe, in my ſimple coniectures; but that is all one: if Sir Iohn Falſtaffe haue committed diſparagements vnto you▪ I am of the Church and will be glad to doe my beneuolence, to make attonements and compremiſes betweene you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: The Councell ſhall heare it, it is a Riot.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: It is not meet the Councell heare a Riot: there is no feare of Got in a Riot: The Councell (looke you) ſhall deſire to heare the feare of Got, and not to heare a Riot: take your viza-ments in that.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ha; o'my life, if I were yong againe, the ſword ſhould end it.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: It is petter that friends is the ſword, and end it: and there is alſo another deuice in my praine, which peraduenture prings goot diſcretions with it. There is Anne Page, which is daughter to Maſter Thomas Page, which is pretty virginity.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Miſtris Anne. Page? ſhee has browne haire, and ſpeakes ſmall like a woman.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: It is that ferry perſon for all the world, as iuſt as you will deſire, and ſeuen hundred pounds of Moneies, and Gold, & Siluer, is her Grand▪ ſire vpon his deaths-bed (Got deliuer to a ioyfull reſurrections) giue, when ſhe is able to ouertake ſeuenteene yeeres old. It were a goot motion, if we leaue our pribbles and prabbles, and deſire a marriage betweene Maſter▪ Abraham, and Miſtris Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Did her Grand, ſire leaue her ſeauen hundred pound▪

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: I, and her father is make her a petter penny.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I know the young Gentlewoman, ſhe has good gifts.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Seuen hundred pounds, & poſſibilities, is goot gifts.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Wel, let vs ſee honeſt Maſter Page is Falſtaffe there▪

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Shall I tell you a lye? I doe deſpiſe a lyer, as I doe deſpiſe one that is falſe, or as I deſpiſe one that is not true: the Knight Sir Iohn is there, and I beſeech you be ruled by your well-willers: I will peat the doore for Maſter Page. What hoa? Got-pleſſe your houſe heere.

sp.speaker: Maſter Page.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Euen.
sp.p: Here is go 't's pleſting and your friend, and Iuſtice Shallow, & heere young Maſter Slender: that peraduentures ſhall tell you another tale, if matters grow to your likings.

sp.speaker: Maſter Page.
sp.p: I am glad to ſee your Worſhips well: I thanke you for my Veniſon Maſter Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Maſter Page, I am glad to ſee you: much good doe it your good heart: I wiſh'd your Veniſon better, it was ill killed: how doth good Miſtreſſe Page? and I thanke you alwaies with my heart, la▪ with my heart.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Sir, I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir, I thanke you: by yea, and no I doe.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: I am glad to ſee you, good Maſter Slender.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: How do's your fallow Greyhound, Sir, I heard ſay he was out▪ run on Cotſall.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: It could not be iudg'd, Sir,

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: You'll not confeſſe: you'll not confeſſe.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: That hee will not, 'tis your fault: 'tis your fault: 'tis a good dogge.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: A Cur, Sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir: hee's a good dog, and a faire dog, can there be more ſaid? he is good and faire. Is Sir Iohn Falſtaffe heerr?

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: Sir, hee is within: and I would I could doe a good office betweene you.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: It is ſpoke as a Chriſtians ought to ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: He hath wrong'd me Maſter Page.)

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: Sir, he doth in ſome ſort confeſſe it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: If it be confeſſed, it is not redreſſed; is not that ſo (M. Page?) he hath wrong'd me, indeed he hath, at a word he hath: belecue me, Robert Shallow Eſquire, ſaith hee is wronged.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: Here comes Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Now, Maſter Shallow, you'll complaine of me to the King?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Knight, you haue beaten my men, kill'd my deere, and broke open my Lodge.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: But not kiſs'd your Keepers daughter?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Tut, a pin: this ſhall be anſwer'd.

lg.l: I will anſwer it ſtrait, I haue done all this:
That is now anſwer'd.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: The Councell ſhall know this.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: 'T were better for you if it were known in Councell: you'll be laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Pauca verba; (Sir Iohn) good worts.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good worts? good Cabidge; Slender, I broke your head: what matter haue you againſt me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Marry ſir, I haue matter in my head againſt you, and againſt your cony-catching Raſcals, Bardolf, Nym, and Piſtoll.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You Banbery Cheeſe.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: How now, Mephoſtophilus?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Slice, I ſay; pauca, pauca: Slice, that's my humor:

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Where's Simple my man? can you tell, Coſen?

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p: Peace, I pray you▪ now let vs vnderſtand: there is three Vmpires in this matter, as I vnderſtand; that is, Maſter Page (fidelicet Maſter Page,) and there is my ſelfe, (fidelicet my ſelfe) and the three party is (laſtly, and finally) mine Hoſt of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: We three to heare it, and end it between them:

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Ferry goo't, I will make a priefe of it in my notebooke, and we will afterwards orke vpon the cauſe, with as great diſcreetly as we can.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Piſtoll.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: He heares with eares.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: The Teuill and his Tam: what phraſe is this? hee heares with eare? why, it is affectations.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Piſtoll, did you picke M. Slenders purſe?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I, by theſe gloues did he, or I would I might neuer come in mine owne great chamber againe elſe, of ſeauen groates in mill-ſixpences, and two Edward Shouelboords, that coſt me two ſhilling and two pence a peece of Yead Miller: by theſe gloues.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Is this true, Piſtoll?

sp.speaker: Fuan.
sp.p: No, it is falſe, if it is a picke-purſe.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: Ha, thou mountaine Forreyner: Sir Iohn, and Maſter mine, I combat challenge of this Latine Bilboe: word of deniall in thy labras here; word of deniall; froth, and ſcum thou lieſt.

sp.speaker: Slen▪
sp.p: By theſe gloues, then 'twas he.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Be auis'd ſir, and paſſe good humours: I will ſay marry trap with you, if you runne the nut-hooks humor on me, that is the very note of it.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: By this hat, then hee in the red face had it: for though I cannot remember what I did when you made me drunke, yet I am not altogether an aſſe.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What ſay you Scarlet, and Iohn?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why ſit, (for my part) I ſay the Gentleman had drunke himſelfe out of his fiue ſentences.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: It is his fi • e ſences: fie, what the ignorance is.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And being fap, ſir, was (as they ſay) caſheerd: and ſo concluſions paſt the Car-eires.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I, you ſpake in Latten then to: but 'tis no matter; Ile nere be drunke whilſt I liue againe, but in honeſt, ciuill, godly company for this tricke: if I be drunke, Ile bee drunke with thoſe that haue the feare of God, and not with drunken knaues.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: So got udge me, that is a vertuous minde.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You heare all theſe matters deni'd, Gentlemen; you heare it.

sp.speaker: Ma. Page.
sp.p: Nay daughter, carry the wine in, wee'll drinke within.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Oh heauen: This is Miſtreſſe Anne Page:

sp.speaker: Maſter Page.
sp.p: How now Miſtris Ford?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Miſtris Ford, by my troth you are very well met: by your leaue good Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Maſter Page.
sp.p: Wife bid theſe gentlemen welcome: come, we haue a hot Veniſon paſty to dinner; Come gentlemen, I hope we ſhall drinke downe all vnkindneſſe.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I had rather then forty ſhillings I had my booke of Songs and Sonnets heere: How now Simple, where haue you beene? I muſt wait on my ſelfe, muſt I? you haue not the booke of Riddles about you, haue you?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Booke of Riddles? why did you not lend it to Alice Short-cake vpon Alhallowmas laſt, a fortnight afore Michaelmas.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Come Coz, come Coz, wee ſtay for you: a word with you Coz: marry this there is as 'twere a tender, a kinde of tender, made a faire-off by Sir Hugh here: doe you vnderſtand me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I Sir, you ſhall finde me reaſonable, if it be ſo, I ſhall doe that that it reaſon.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Nay, but vnderſtand me▪

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: So I doe Sir.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Giue care to his motions; (Maſter Slender) I will deſcription the matter to you, if you be capacity of it.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Nay, I will doe as my Cozen Shallow ſaies: I pray you pardon me, he's a Iuſtice of Peace in his Countrie, ſimple though I ſtand here.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: But that is not the queſtion: the queſtion is concerning your marriage.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I, there's the point Sir.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Marry is it▪ the very point of it, to Miſt. Anne▪ Page.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Why if it be ſo▪ I will marry hervpon any reaſonable demands.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: But can you affection the'o man, let vs command to know that of your mouth, or of your lips: for diners Philoſophers hold, that the lips is parcell of the mouth▪ therefore preciſely, can you carry your good will to the maide?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Coſen Abraham Slender, can you loue her?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I hope ſir, I will doe as it ſhall become one that would doe reaſon.

sp.speaker: Euan:
sp.p:
Nay, got's Lords, and his Ladies, you muſt ſpeake
poſſitable, if you can carry-her your deſires towards her.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: That you muſt.
Will you, (vpon good dowry) marry her?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I will doe a greater thing then that, vpon your requeſt (Coſen) in any reaſon.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Nay conceiue mee, conceiue mee, (ſweet Coz): what I doe is to pleaſure you (Coz) can you loue the maid?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I will marry her (Sir) at your requeſt; but if there be no great loue in the beginning, yet Heauen may decreaſe it vpon better acquaintance, when wee are married, and haue more occaſion to know one another; I hope vpon familiarity will grow more content; but if you ſay mary-her, I will mary-her, that I am freely diſſolued, and diſſolutely.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: It is a fery diſcretion-anſwere; ſaue the fall is in the'ord, diſſolutely; the ort is (according to our meaning) reſolutely: his meaning is good.

sp.speaker: Sh▪
sp.p: I, I thinke my Coſen meant well.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I or elſe I would I might be hang'd (la▪)

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Here comes faire Miſtris Anne; would I were yong for your ſake, Miſtris Anne.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The dinner is on the Table, my Father deſires your worſhips company.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: I will wait on him, (faire Miſtris Anee.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Od's pleſſed-will; I will not be abſence at the grace

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Wil't pleaſe your worſhip to come in, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: No, I thanke you forſooth, hartely; I am very well.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The dinner attends you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: I am not a hungry, I thanke you, forſooth; goe Sirha, for all you are my man, goe waite vpon my Coſen Shallow; a Iuſtice of peace ſometime may be beholding to his friend, for a Man; I keepe but three Men and a Boy yet, till my Mother be dead; but what though, yet I liue like a a poore Gentleman borne.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I may not goe in without your worſhip; they will not ſit till you come.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I▪faith, ile eate nothing, I thanke you as much as though I did.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: I pray you Sir walke in.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I had rather walke here (I thanke you) I bruiz'd my ſhin th'other day, with playing at Sword and Dagger with a Maſter of Fence (three veneys for a diſh of ſlew'd Prunes) and by my troth, I cannot abide the ſmell of hot meat ſince. Why doe your dogs barke ſo? be there Beares ith' Towne?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I thinke there are, Sir, I heard them talk'd of.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I loue the ſport well, but I ſhall as ſoone quarrell at it, as any man in England, you are afraid if you ſee the Beare looſe, are you not?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I indeede Sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: That's meate and drinke to me now; I haue ſeene Sackerſon looſe, twenty times, and haue taken him by the Chaine, but (I warrant you) the women haue ſo cride and ſhrekt at it, that it paſt. But women indeede, cannot abide'em, they are very ill-fauour'd rough things.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: Come, gentle M. Slender, come; we ſtay for you.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ile eate nothing, I thanke you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: By cocke and pie, you ſhall not chooſe, Sir: come, come.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Nay, pray you lead the way.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: Come on Sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Miſtris Anne: your ſelfe ſhall goe firſt.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Not I Sir, pray you keepe on.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Truely I will not goe firſt, truely-la▪ I will not doe you that wrong.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I pray you Sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ile rather be vnmannerly, then troubleſome, you do your ſelfe wrong indeede-la.

div.head: Scena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Euans, and Simple.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Go your wayes, and aske of Doctor Caius houſe,
which is the way; and there dwels one Miſtris Quickly; which is in the manner of his Nurſe; or his dry-Nurſe; or his Cooke; or his Laundry; his Waſher, and his Ringer.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Nay, it is petter yet; giue her this letter; for▪t is a'oman that altogeathers acquaintance with Miſtris Anne Page; and the Letter is to deſire, and require her to ſolicite your Maſters deſires, to Miſtris Anne Page. I pray you bee gon: I will make an end of my dinner; ther's Pippins and Cheeſe to come.

div.head: Scena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Falſtaeffe, Hoſt, Bardolfe, Nym, Piſtoll, Page.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Mine Hoſt of the Garter?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: What ſaies my Bully Rooke? ſpeake ſchollerly, and wiſely.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Truely mine Hoſt; I muſt turne away ſome of my followers.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Diſcard, (bully Hercules) caſheere; let them wag; trot, trot.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I ſit at ten pounds a weeke.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Thou'rt an Emperor (Ceſar, Keiſer and Pheazar) I will entertaine Bardolfe; he ſhall draw; he ſhall tap; ſaid I well (bully Hector?)

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Doe ſo (good mine Hoſt.)

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: I haue ſpoke, let him follow, let me ſee thee froth, and liue: I am at a word: follow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Bardolfe, follow him; a Tapſter is a good trade, an old Cloake, makes a new Ierkin, a wither'd Seruingman, a freſh Tapſter; goe, adew.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: It is a life that I haue deſir'd, I will thriue.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: O baſe hungarian wight, wilt thou the ſpigot wield:

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: He was gotten in drinke, is not the humor conceited

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I am glad I am ſo acquit of this Tinderbox, his Thefts were too open, his filching was like an vnskilfull Singer, he kept not time.

sp.speaker: Nim.
sp.p: The good humor is to ſteale at a minuntes reſt.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: Conuay: the wiſe it call: Steale? foh: a fico for the phraſe.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well ſirs, I am almoſt out at heeles.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: Why then let Kibes enſue.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: There is no remedy: I muſt conicatch, I muſt ſhift,

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: Yong Rauens muſt haue foode.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Which of you know Ford of this Towne?

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: I ken the wight; he is of ſubſtance good.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: My honeſt Lads, I will tell you what I am about.

sp.speaker: Piſt,
sp.p: Two yards, and more.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No quips now Piſtoll; (Indeede I am in the waſt two yards about; but I am now about no waſte: I am about thrift) briefely; I doe meane to make loue to Fords wife; I ſpie entertainment in her, ſhee diſcourſes, ſhee craues, ſhe giues the leere of inuitation; I can conſtrue the action of her familier ſtile, and the hardeſt voice of her behauior (to be engliſh'd rightly) is I am Sir Iohn Falſtafs.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: He hath ſtudied her will; and tranſlated her will out of honeſty, into Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The Anchor is deepe; will that humor paſſe?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Now, the report goes, ſhe has all the rule of her husbands Purſe; he hath a legend of Angels.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: As many diuels entertaine; and to her Boy ſay I.

sp.speaker: Ni
sp.p: The humor riſes it is good; humor me the angels.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I haue writ me here a letter to her; and here another to Pages wife, who euen now gaue me good eyes too; examind my parts with moſt iudicious illiads; ſometimes the beame of her view, guilded my foote, ſometimes my portly belly.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: Then did the Sun on dung-hill ſhine.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I thanke thee for that humour.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
O ſhe did ſo courſe o're my exteriors with ſuch a greedy intention, that the appetite of her eye, did ſeeme to ſcorch mee vp like a burning-glaſſe; here's another letter to her; She beares the Purie too; Shee is a Region in Guiana; all gold, and bountie; I will be Cheaters to them both, and they ſhall be Exchequers to mee; they
ſhall be my Eaſt and Weſt Indies, and I will trade to them both; Goe, beare thou this Letter to Miſtris Page; and thou this to Miſtris Ford; wee will thriue (Lads) wee will thriue.

lg.l: Shall I Sir Pandarus of Troy become,
And by my ſide weare Steele? then Lucifer take all.
I will run no baſe humor; here take the humor-Letter;
I will keepe the hauior of reputation.
Hold Sirha, beare you theſe Letters rightly,
Saile like my Pinnaſſe to theſe golden ſhores.
Rogues, hence, auaunt, vaniſh like haile-ſtones; goe,
Trudge; plod away ith' hooſe: ſeeke ſhelter, packe,
Falſtaffe will learne the honor of the age,
French thrift, you Rogues, my ſelfe, and skirted Page.
Let Vultures gripe thy guts, for gourd, and Fullam
holds, and high and low beguiles the rich and poore,
Teſter ile haue in pouch when thou ſhalt lacke,
Baſe Phrygian Turke.
I haue opperations.
Which be humors of reuenge.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: Wilt thou reuenge?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: By Welkin, and her Star.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: With wit, or Steele?

lg.l: With both the humors, I;
I will diſcuſſe the humour of this Loue to Ford.
And I to Page ſhall eke vnfold
How Falſtaffe (varlet vile)
His Doue will proue; his gold will hold,
And his ſoft couch defile.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: My humor ſhall not coole; I will incenſe Ford, to deale with poyſon; I will poſſeſſe him with yallowneſſe, for the reuolt of mine is dangerous; that is my true humour.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Thou art the Mars of Malecontents; I ſecond thee; troope on.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: Scoena Quarta:
div.stage: Enter Miſtris Quickly, Simple, Iohn Rugby, Doctor Caius, Fenton.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: What, Iohn Rugby, I pray thee goe to the Caſement, and ſee if you can ſee my Maſter, Maſter Doctor Caius comming; if he do (I'faith) and finde any body in the houſe; here will be an old abuſing of Gods patience, and the Kings Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Ile goe watch.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Goe, and we'll haue a poſſet for't ſoone at night, (in faith) at the latter end of a Sea-cole-fire: An honeſt, willing, kinde fellow, as euer ſeruant ſhall come in houſe withall: & I warrant you, no tel-tale, nor no breedebate: his worſt fault is, that he is giuen to prayer; hee is ſomething peeuiſh that way: but no body but has his fault: but let that paſſe. Peter Simple, you ſay your name is?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I, for fault of a better.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: And Maſter Slender's your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I forſooth.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Do's he not weare a great round Beard, like a Glouers paring-knife?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: No forſooth, he hath but a little wee-face; with a little yellow Beard, a Caine colourd Beard.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: A ſofttly-ſprighted man, is he not?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I forſooth, but he is as tall a man of his hands, as any is betweene this and his head; hee hath fought with a Warrener.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: How ſay you; oh, I ſhould remember him, do's hee not hold vp his head (as it were?) and ſtrut in his gate?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Yes indeede do's he.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Well, heauen ſend Anne Page, no worſe fortune, Tell Maſter Parſon, Euans, I will doe what I can for your Maſter; Anne is a good girle, and I wiſh—

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Out alas, here comes my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
Wee ſhall all be ſhent; Run in here, good young
man, goe into this Cloſſet: hee will not ſtay long? what Iohn Rugby? Iohn; what Iohn I ſay? goe Iohn, goe enquire for my Maſter, I doubt hee be not well, that hee comes not home, (and downe, downe, downe'a, &c.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Vat is you ſing? I doe not like des-toyes, pray you goe and vetch me in my Cloſſt, vnboyteene verd; a Box, a greene-a-Box; do intend vat I ſpeake? greene-a-Box.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: I forſooth ile fetch it you: I am glad hee went not in himſelfe: if hee had found the yong man he would haue beene horne-mad.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Fe, fe, fe, fe, mai foy, il fait for chando, le man voi a le Court la grand affaires.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Is it this Sir?

lg.l: Ouy mette le au mon pocket, de-peech quickly:
Vere is dat knaue Rugby?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: What Iohn Rugby, Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: You are Iohn Rugby, and you are Iacke Rugby; Come, take your Rapier, and come after my heele to the Court.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: 'Tis ready Sir, here in the Porch.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: By my trot, I tarry too long, od's-me: que ay ie oublie dere is ſome Simples in my Cloſſet, dat I vill not for the varld I ſhall leaue behinde.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Ay-me, he'll finde the yong man there, and be mad▪

lg.l: O Diable, Diable; vat is in my Cloſſet?
Villaine, La-roone; Rugby, my Rapier.

sp.speaker: Qu,
sp.p: Good Maſter be content.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Wherefore ſhall I be content-a?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: The yong man is an honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: What ſhall de honeſt man do in my Cloſſet, here is no honeſt man dat ſhall come in my Cloſſet.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: I beſeech you be not ſo flegmaticke; heare the truth of it. He came of an errand to mee, from Parſon Hugh.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Vell.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I forſooth: to deſire her to—

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Peace, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Peace-a-your tongue: ſpeake-a-your Tale.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: To deſire this honeſt Gentlewoman (your Maid) to ſpeake a good word to Miſtris Anne Page, for my Maſter in the way of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: This is all indeed-la: but ile nere put my finger in the fire, and neede not.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Sir Hugh ſend-a you? Rugby, ballow me ſome paper: tarry you a littell-a while.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: I am glad hee is ſo quiet: if hee had bin throughly moued, you ſhould haue heard him ſo loud, and ſo melancholly; but notwithſtanding man, Ile doe yoe your Maſter what good I can; and the very yea, and the no is that French Doctor my Maſter, (I may call him my Maſter, looke you, for I keepe his houſe; and I waſh, ring, brew, bake, ſcowre, dreſſe meate and drinke, make the beds, and doe all my ſelfe.)

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: 'Tis a great charge to come vnder one bodies hand.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Are you a uis'd o' that? you ſhall finde it a great charge: and to be vp early, and downe late; but notwithſtanding, (to tell you in your eare, I would haue no words of it) my Maſter himſelfe is in loue with Miſtris Anne Page; but notwithſtanding that I know Ans mind, that's neither heere nor there.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: You, Iack 'Nape; glue-'a this Letter to Sir Hugh, by gar it is a ſhallenge: I will cut his troat in de Parke, and I will teach a ſcuruy Iack-a-nape Prieſt to meddle, or make:—you may be gon: it is not good you tarry here; by gar I will cut all his two ſtones; by gar, he ſhall not haue a ſtone to throw at his dogge.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Alas, he ſpeakes but for his friend.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: It is no matter'a v • r dat; do not you tell-a-me dat I ſhall haue Anne Page for my ſelfe? by gar, I vill kill de Iacke Prieſt; and I haue appointed mine Hoſt of de Iarteer to meaſure our weapon, by gar, I will my ſelfe haue Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Sir, the maid loues you, and all ſhall bee well; Wee muſt giue folkes leaue to pr • te; what the good ier.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Rugby, come to the Court with me: by gar, if I haue not Anne Page, I ſhall turne your head out of my dore: follow my heeles, Rugby.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: You ſhall haue An-fooles head of your owne; No, I know Ans mind for that; neuer a woman in Windſor knowes more of Ans minde then I doe, nor can doe more then I doe with her, I thanke heauen.

sp.speaker: Fenton.
sp.p: Who's with in there, hoa?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Who's there, I troa? Come neere the houſe I pray you.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: How now (good woman) how doſt thou?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: The better that it pleaſes your good Worſhip to aske?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: What newes? how do's pretty Miſtris Anne?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: In truth Sir, and ſhee is pretty, and honeſt, and gentle, and one that is your friend, I can tell you that by the way, I praiſe heauen for it.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Shall I doe any good thinkſt thou? ſhall I not looſe my ſuit?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Troth Sir, all is in his hands aboue; but notwithſtanding (Maſter Fenton) Ile be ſworne on a booke ſhee loues you; haue not your Worſhip a wart aboue your eye?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Yes marry haue I, what of that?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Well, thereby hangs a tale; good faith, it is ſuch another Nan; (but (I deteſt) an honeſt maid as euer broke bread: wee had an howres talke of that wart; I ſhall neuer laugh but in that maids company, but (indeed) ſhee is giuen too much to Allicholy and muſing; but for you—well—goe too—.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Well, I ſhall ſee her to day; hold, there's money for thee. Let mee haue thy voice in my behalfe; if thou ſeeſt her before me, commend me.—

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Willi • ? I faith that wee will; And I will tell your Worſhip more of the Wart, the next time we haue confidence, and of other wooers.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Well, fare-well, I am in great haſte now.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Fare-well to your Worſhip; truely an honeſt
Gentleman: but Anne loues him not, for I know Ans minde as well as another do's, out vpon't, what haue I forgot.

div.head: Scoena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Miſtris Page, Miſtris Ford, Maſter Page, Maſter Ford, Piſtoll, Nim, Quickly, Hoſt, Shallow.

sp.speaker: Mi. Page.
sp.p: What, haue I ſcap'd Loue-letters in the hollyday-time of my beauty, and am I now a ſubiect for them? let me ſee.

Aske me no reaſon why I loue you, for though Loue vſe Reaſon for his preciſian, hee admits him not for his Counſailour: you are not young, no more am I: goe to then, there's ſimpathie: you are merry▪ ſo am I: ha, ha, then there's more ſimpathie: you loue ſacke, and ſo doe I: would yout deſire better ſimpathie? Let it ſuffice thee (Miſtris Page) at the leaſt if the Loue of Souldier can ſuffice, that I loue thee: I will not ſay pitty mee, 'tis not a Souldier-like phraſe; but I ſay▪ loue me:

lg.l: By me, thine owne true Knight, by day or night:
Or any kinde of light, with all his might,
For thee to fight, Iohn Falſtaffe.
What a Herod of Iurie is this? O wicked, wicked world.
One that is well-nye worne to peeces with age
To ſhow himſelfe a young Gallant? What an vnwaied

sp.p: Behauiour hath this Flemiſh drunkard pickt (with The Deuills name) out of my conuerſation, that hee dares In this manner aſſay me? why, hee hath not beene thrice In my Company, what ſhould I ſay to him? I was then Frugall of my mirth: (heauen forgiue mee,) why ile Exhibit a Bill in the Parliament for the putting downe of men, how ſhall I be reueng'd on him? for reueng'd I will be? as ſure as his guts are made of puddings.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Miſtris Page, truſt me, I was going to your houſe.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: And truſt me, I was going to you: you looke very ill.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Nay, ile nere beleeue that; I haue to ſhew to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page
sp.p: 'Faith but you doe in my minde.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Fords
sp.p: Well: I doe then; yet I ſay, I could ſhew you to the contrary; O Miſtris Page, giue mee ſome counſaile.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: What's the matter, woman?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: O woman; if it were not for one trifling reſpect, I could come to ſuch honour.

sp.speaker: Miſ▪ Page.
sp.p: Hang the trifle (woman) take the honour; what is it? diſpence with trifles; what is it?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: If I would but goe to hell, for an eternall moment, or ſo; I could be knighted.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: What thou lieſt? Sir Alice Ford? theſe Knights will hacke, and ſo thou ſhouldſt not alter the article of thy Gentry.

sp.speaker: Miſ▪ Ford.
sp.p: Wee burne day-light; heere, read, read; perceiue how I might be knighted, I ſhall thinke the worſe of fat men, as long as I haue an eye to make difference of mens liking; and yet hee would not ſweare: praiſe womens modeſty; and gaue ſuch orderly and welbehaued reproofe to all vncomelineſſe, that I would haue ſworn his diſpoſition would haue gone to the truth of his words: but they doe no more adhere and keepe place together, then the hundred Pſalmes to the tune of Greeneſleeues: What tempeſt (I troa) threw this Whale, (with ſo many Tuns of oyle in his belly) a'ſhoare at Windſor? How ſhall I be reuenged on him? I thinke the beſt way were, to entertaine him with hope, till the wicked fire of luſt haue melted him in his owne greaſe. Did you euer heare the like?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p:
Letter for letter; but that the name of Page and Ford differs; to thy great comfort in this myſtery of ill opinions, heer's the twyn-brother of thy Letter; but let thine inherit firſt, for I proteſt mine neuer ſhall: I warrant hee hath a thouſand of theſe Letters, writ
with blancke ſpace for different names (ſure more) & theſe are of the ſecond edition; he wil print them out of doubt, for he cares not what he puts into the preſſe, when he would put vs two; I had rather be a Gianteſſe & lye vnder Mount
• elion. Well; I will finde you twentie laſcioious Turtles ere one chaſte man.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Why this is the very ſame; the very hand, the very words, what doth he thinke of vs?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Nay I know not; it makes me almoſt readie to wrangle with mine owne honeſty; Ile entertaine my ſelfe like one that I am not acquainted withall, for ſure vnleſſe hee know ſome ſtraine in mee, that I know not my ſelfe, hee would neuer haue boorded me in this furie.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Boording, call you it? Ile be ſure to keepe him aboue decke.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: So will I, if hee come vnder my hatches, Ile neuer to Sea againe. Let's be reueng'd on him; let's appoint him a meeting, giue him a ſhow of comfort in his Suite, and lead him on with a fine baited delay, till hee hath pawn'd his horſes to mine Hoſt of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Nay, I will conſent to act any villany againſt him, that may not ſully the charineſſe of our honeſty; oh that my husband ſaw this Letter; it would giue eternall food to his iealouſie.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Why looke where he comes; and my good man too; hee's as farre from iealouſie, as I am from giuing him cauſe, and that (I hope) is an vnmeaſurable diſtance:

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: You are the happier woman.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Let's conſult together againſt this greaſie Knight; Come hither.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well, I hope, it be not ſo.

lg.l: Hope is a curtall-dog in ſome affaires;
Sir Iohn affects thy wife.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Why ſir, my wife is not young.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p:
He wooes both high and low, both rich and poore, both young and old, one with another (Ford) he loues the
Gally-mawfry (Ford) perpend.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Loue my wife?

lg.l: With liuer, burning hot: preuent:
Ot goe thou like Sir Acteon he, with
Ring-wood at thy heeles: O, odious is the name.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: What name Sir?

lg.l: The horne I ſay▪ Farewell.
Take heed, haue open eye, for theeues doe foot by night.
Take heed, ere ſommer comes, or Cuckoo▪ birds doe ſing.
Away ſir Corporall Nim.
Beleeue it (Page) he ſpeakes ſence.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I will be patient; I will finde out this.

sp.speaker: Nim.
sp.p: And this is true; I like not the humor of lying, hee haue wronged mee in ſome humors; I ſhould haue borne the humour'd Letter to her, but I haue a ſword, and it ſhall bite vpon my neceſſitie, he loues your wife; There's the ſh •• t and the long: My name is Corporall Nim, I ſpeak, and I auouch; 'tis true: my name is Nim, and Falſtoffe loues your wife, adieu, I loue not the humour of bread & cheeſe: adieu.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: The humour of it (quoth'a▪) heere's a fellow frights Engliſh out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I will ſeeke out Falſtaffe.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I neuer heard ſuch a drawling-affecting rogue▪

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: If I doe finde it: well▪

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I will not beleeue ſuch a Catai •• , though the Prieſt o'th'Towne commended him for a true man.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: 'Twas a good ſenſible fellow, well.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: How now Meg?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Whither goe you (George?) harke you.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: How now (ſweet Frank) why art thou me▪ lancholy?

lg.l: I melancholy? I am not melancholy:
Get you home, goe.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Faith, thou haſt ſome crochets in thy head, Now, will you goe, Miſtris Page?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p:
Haue with you, you'll come to dinner George▪ Looke who comes yonder; ſhee ſhall bee our Meſſenger
to this paltrie Knight:

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Truſt me, I thought on her; ſhee'll fit it:

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: You are come to ſee my daughter Anne?

sp.speaker: Qui,
sp.p: I forſooth: and I pray how do's good Miſtreſſe Anne?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Go in with vs and ſee, wee haue an houres talke with you.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: How now Maſter Ford?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: You heard what this knaue told me, did you not?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes, and you heard what the other told me?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Doe you thinke there is truth in them?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Hang ▪em ſlaues: I doe not thinke the Knight would offer it: But theſe that accuſe him in his intent towards our wiues, are a yoake of his diſcarded men, very rogues, now they be out of ſeruice▪

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Were they his men?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Marry were they.

lg.l: I like it neuer the better for that,
Do's he lye at the Garter?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I marry do's he: if hee ſhould intend this voyage toward my wife, I would turne her looſe to him, and what hee gets more of her, then ſharpe words, let it lye on my head.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I doe not miſdoubt my wife, but I would be Ioath to turne them together, a man may bee too confident, I would haue nothing lye on my head, I cannot be thus ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Looke where my ranting-Hoſt of the Garter comes: there is either liquor in his pate, or mony in his purſe, when hee lookes ſo merrily: How now mine Hoſt?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: How now Bully-Rooke, thou'rt a Gentleman, Caueleiro Iuſtice, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I follow, (mine Hoſt) I follow, Good-euen, and twenty (good Maſter Page) Maſter Page, will you go with vs? we haue ſport in hand.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Tell him Caueleiro-Iuſtice: tell him Bully-Rooke.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir, there is a fray to be fought, betweene Sir Huge the Welch Prieſt, and Caius the French Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Good mine Hoſt o'th'Garter, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: What ſaiſt thou, my Bully-Rooke?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Will you goe with vs to behold it? My merry Hoſt hath had the meaſuring of their weapons, and (I thinke) appointed them contrary places: for (beleeue me) I heare the Parſon is no Ieſter▪ harke, I will tell you what our ſport ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Haſt thou no ſuit againſt my Knight? my gueſt-Caualeire?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: None, I proteſt, but ile giue you a pottle of burn'd ſacke, to giue me recourſe to him, and tell him my name is Broome, onely for a ieſt.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: My hand, (Bully,) thou ſhalt haue egreſſe and regreſſe, (ſaid I well▪) and thy name ſhall be Broome. It is a merry Knight, will you goe An-heires?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Haue with you mine Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I haue heard the French-man hath good skill in his Rapier.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Tut Sir, I could haue told you more. In theſe times you ſtand on diſtance, your Paſſes, Stoccado's, and I know not what: 'tis the heart (Maſter Page,) 'tis heere, 'tis heere, I haue ſeene the time, with my long-ſword, I would haue made you fowre tall fellowes skippe like Rattes.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Heere boyes, heere, heere, ſhall we wag?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Haue with you, I had rather heare them ſcold, then fight.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Though Page be a ſecure foole, and ſtands ſo firmely on his wiues frailty: yet, I cannot put-off my opinion ſo eaſily, ſhe was in his company at Pages houſe, and what they made there, I know not. Well, I will looke further into't, and I haue a diſguiſe, to ſound Falſtaffe, if I finde her honeſt, I looſe not my labour, if ſhee be otherwiſe, 'tis labour well beſtowed.

div.head: Scoena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Falſtaffe, Piſtoll, Robin, Quickly, Bardolffe, Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I will not lend thee a penny.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: Why then the world's mine Oyſter, which I, with ſword will open.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Not a penny, I haue beene content (Sir,) you ſhould lay my countenance to pawne; I haue granted vpon my good friends for three Repreeues for, and your Coach▪ fellow Nim, or elſe you had look'd through the grate, like a Geminy of Baboones: I am damn'd in hell, for ſwearing to Gentlemen my friends, you were good Souldiers, and tall-fellowes. And when Miſtreſſe Briget loſt the handle of her Fan, I took't vpon mine honour thou hadſt it not.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: Didſt not thou ſhare? hadſt thou not fifteene pence?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Reaſon, you roague, reaſon; thinkſt thou Ile endanger my ſoule, gratis? at a word, hang no more about mee, I am no gibbet for you: goe, a ſhort knife, and a throng, to your Mannor of Pickt-hatch; goe, you'll not beare a Letter for mee you roague? you ſtand vpon your honour: why, (thou vnconfinable baſeneſſe) it is as much as I can doe to keepe the termes of my honour preciſe; I, I, I my ſelfe ſometimes, leauing the feare of heauen on the left hand, and hiding mine honor in my neceſſity, am faine to ſhuffle: to hedge, and to lurch, and yet, you Rogue, will en-ſconce your raggs; your Cat-a-Mountaine-lookes, your red-lattice phraſes, & your boldbeatingoathes, vnder the ſhelter of your honor? you will not doe it? you?

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: I doe relent: what would thou more of man?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Sir, here's a woman would ſpeake with you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Let her approach.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Giue your worſhip good morrow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good-morrow, good-wife.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Not ſo, and't pleaſe your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good, maid then.

lg.l: Ile be ſworne.
As my mother was the firſt houre I was borne.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I doe beleeue the ſwearer; what with me?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Shall I vouch-ſafe your worſhip a word, or two?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Two thouſand (faire woman) and ile vouchſafe thee the hearing.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: There is one Miſtreſſe Ford, (Sir) I pray come a little neerer this waies; I my ſelfe dwell with Maſter Doctor Caius.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, on; Miſtris Ford, you ſay.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Your worſhip ſaies very true; I pray your worſhip come a little neerer this waies.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I warrant thee, no-bodie heares; mine owne people, mine owne people.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Are they ſo? heauen-bleſſe them, and make them his Seruants.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well; Miſtreſſe Ford, what of her?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Why, Sir; ſhee's a good creature; Lord, Lord your Worſhip's a wanton: well, heauen forgiue you, and all of vs, I pray—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Miſtreſſe Ford, come, Miſtreſſe Ford.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Marry this is the ſhort, and the long of it; you haue brought her into ſuch a Canaries, as 'tis wonderfull; the beſt Courtier of them all (when the Court lay at Windſor) could neuer haue brought her to ſuch a Canarie: yet there has beene Knights, and Lords, and Gentlemen, with their Coaches; I warrant you Coach after Coach, letter after letter, gift aftee gift, ſmelling ſo ſweetly; all Muske, and ſo ruſhling, I warrant you, in ſilke and golde, and in ſuch alligant tearmes, and in ſuch wine and ſuger of the beſt, and the faireſt, that would haue wonne any womans heart: and I warrant you, they could neuer get an eye-winke of her: I had my ſelfe twentie Angels giuen me this morning, but I defie all Angels in
any ſuch ſort, as they ſay) but in the way of honeſty: and I warrant you, they could neuer get her ſo much as ſippe on a cup with the prowdeſt of them all, and yet there has beene Earles; nay, (which is more) Pentioners, but I warrant you all is one with her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: But what ſaies ſhee to mee? bee briefe my good ſhee-Mercurie.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Marry, ſhe hath receiu'd your Letter; for the which ſhe thankes you a thouſand times; and ſhee giues you to notifie, that her husband will be abſence from his houſe, betweene ten and eleuen.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ten, and eleuen.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: I, forſooth; and then you may come and ſee the picture (ſhe ſayes) that you wot of; Maſter Ford her huſband will be from home: alas, the ſweet woman leads an ill life with him; hee's a very iealouſie-man; ſhee leades a vere framepold life with him, (good heart.)

lg.l: Ten, and eleuen.
Woman, commend me to her, I will not faile her.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Why, you ſay well: But I haue another meſſenger to your worſhip: Miſtreſſe Page hath her heartie commendations to you to; and let me tell you in your eare, ſhee's as fartuous a ciuill modeſt wife, and one (I tell you) that will not miſſe you morning nor euening prayer, as any is in Windſor, who ere be the other: and ſhee bade mee tell your worſhip, that her husband is ſeldome from home, but ſhee hopes there will come a time. I neuer knew a woman ſo doate vpon a man; ſurely I thinke you haue charmes, la: yes in truth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Not I, I aſſure thee; ſetting the attraction of my good parts aſide, I haue no other charmes.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Bleſſing on your heart for't:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: But I pray thee tell me this; has Fords wife, and Pages wiſe acquainted each other, how they loue me?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
That were a ieſt indeed they haue not ſo little grace I hope, that were a tricke indeed: But Miſtis Page would deſire you to ſend her your little Page of all loues; her husband has a maruellous infection to the little Page;
and truely Maſter Page is an honeſt man; neuer a wife in Windſor leades a better life then ſhe do's; do what ſhee will, ſay what ſhe will, take all, pay all, goe to bed when ſhee liſt, riſe when ſhe liſt, all is as ſhe will; and truly ſhe deſerues it; for if there be a kinde woman in Windſor, ſhee is one; you muſt ſend her your Page, no remedie.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why, I will.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Nay, but doe ſo then, and looke you, hee may come and goe betweene you both; and in any caſe haue a nay-word, that you may know one anothers minde, and the Boy neuer heede to vnderſtand any thing; for 'tis not good that children ſhould know any wickednes; old folkes you know, haue diſcretion, as they ſay, and know the world.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Farethee-well, commend mee to them both, there's my purſe, I am yet thy debter; Boy, goe along with this woman, this newes diſtracts me.

lg.l: This Puncke is one of Cupids Carriers,
Clap no more ſailes, purſue▪ vp with your fights:
Giue fire; ſhe is my prize, or Ocean whelme all.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Saiſt thou ſo (old Iacke) goe thy waies Ile make more of thy old body then I haue done: will they yet looke after thee? wilt thou after the expence of ſo much money, be now a gainer? good Body, I thanke thee; let them ſay 'tis groſſely done, ſo it bee fairely done, no matter.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Sir Iohn, there's one Maſter Broome below would faine ſpeake with you, and be acquainted with you; and hath ſent your worſhip a mornings draught of Sacke.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Broome is his name?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Call him in: ſuch Broomes are welcome to me, that that ore'flowes ſuch liquor; ah ha, Miſtreſſe Ford and Miſtreſſe Page, haue I encompaſs'd you? goe to, via.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: 'Bleſſe you ſir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: And you ſir; would you ſpeake with me?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I make bold, to preſſe, with ſo little preparation vpon you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
You'r welcome, what's you •
• ill? giue vs leaue Drawer.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Sir, I am a Gentleman that haue ſpent much, my name is Broome.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good Maſter Broome, I deſire more acquaintance of you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Good Sir Iohn, I ſue for yours; not to charge you, for I muſt let you vnderſtand, I thinke my ſelfe in better plight for a Lender, then you are; the which hath ſomething emboldned mee to this vnſeaſon'd intruſion: for they ſay, if money goe before, all waies doe lye open.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Money is a good Souldier (Sir) and will on.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Troth, and I haue a bag of money heere troubles me; if you will helpe to beare it (Sir Iohn) take all, or halfe for eaſing me of the carriage:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Sir, I know not how I may deſerue to bee your Porter.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I will tell you Sir, if you will giue mee the hearing.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Speake (good Maſter Broome) I ſhall be glad to be your Seruant.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Sir, I heare you are a Scholler; (I will be briefe with you) and you haue beene a man long knowne to me, though I had neuer ſo good meanes as deſire, to make my ſelfe acquainted with you. I ſhall diſcouer a thing to you, wherein I muſt very much lay open mine own imperfection: but (good Sir Iohn) as you haue one eye vpon my follies, as you heare them vnfolded, turne another into the Regiſter of your owne, that I may paſſe with a reproofe the eaſier, ſith you your ſelfe know how eaſie it is to be ſuch an offender.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Very well Sir, proceed:

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: There is a Gentlewoman in this Towne, her husbands name is Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I haue long lou'd her, and I proteſt to you, beſtowed much on her; followed her with a doating obſeruance;
Ingroſs'd opportunities to meete her▪ free'd euery ſlight occaſion that could but nigardly giue mee ſight of her▪ not onely brought many preſents to giue her, but haue giuen largely to many, to know what ſhe would haue giuen briefly, I haue purſu'd her, as Loue hath purſud mee, which hath beene on the wing of all occaſions; but whatſoeuer I haue merited, either in my minde, or in my meanes, meede I am ſure I haue receiued none, vnleſſe Experience be a Iewell, that I haue purchaſed at an infinite rate, and that hath taught me to ſay this.

lg.l: ``Loue like a ſhadow flies, when ſubſtance Loue purſues,
``Purſuing that that flies, and flying what purſues▪

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Haue you receiu'd no promiſe of ſatisfaction at her hands?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Haue you importun'd her to ſuch a purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Of what qualitie was your loue then?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Like a faire houſe, built on another mans ground, ſo that I haue loſt my edifice, by miſtaking the place where I erected it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: To what purpoſe haue you vnfolded this to me?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: When I haue told you that, I haue told you all: Some ſay, that though ſhee appeare honeſt to mee, yet in other places ſhee enlargeth hir mirth ſo farre, that there is ſhrewd conſtruction made of her. Now (Sir Iohn) here is the heart of my purpoſe: you are a Gentleman of excellent breeding, admirable diſcourſe, of great admittance, authenticke in your place and perſon, generally allow'd for your many warlike, court-like, and learned preparations.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: O Sir.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Beleeue it, for you know it: there is money, ſpend it, ſpend it, ſpend more; ſpend all I haue, onely giue me ſo much of your time in exchange of it, as to lay an amiable ſiege to the honeſty of this Fords wife: vſe your Art of
wooing; win her to conſent to you; if any man may, you may as ſoone as any.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Would it apply well to the vehemency of your affection that I ſhould win what you would enioy? Methinkes you preſcribe to your ſelfe very prepoſterouſly.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: O, vnderſtand my drift; ſhe dwells ſo ſecurely on the excellency of her honor, that the folly of my ſoule dares not preſent it ſelfe; ſhe is too bright to be look'd againſt. Now, could I come to her with any detection in my hand; my deſires had inſtance and argument to commend themſelues, I could driue her then from the ward of her purity, her reputation, her marriage vow, and a thouſand other her defences, which now are too-too ſtrongly embattaild againſt me; what ſay you too't, Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Maſter Broome, I will firſt make bold with your mony, next, giue me your hand; and laſt, as I am a Gentleman, you ſhall, if you will, enioy Fords wife.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: O good Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I ſay you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Want no money (Sir Iohn) you ſhall want none.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Want no Miſtreſſe Ford (Maſter Broome) you ſhall want none; I ſhall be with her (I may tell you) by her own appointment, euen as you came in to me, her aſſiſtant, or goe betweene, parted from me; I ſay I ſhall be with her betweene ten and eleuen, for at that time the iealious raſcallyknaue her husband will be forth; come you to me at night, you ſhall know how I ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I am bleſt in your acquaintance; do you know Ford Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Hang him (poore Cuckoldly knaue) I know him not: yet I wrong him to call him poore; They ſay the iealous wittolly-knaue hath maſſes of money, for the which his wife ſeemes to me well-fauourd: I will vſe her as the key of the Cuckoldly-rogues Coffer, & ther's my harueſt▪ home.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I would you knew Ford, ſir, that you might auoid him, if you ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Hang him, mechanicall-ſalt-butter rogue; I will ſtare him out of his wits; I will awe-him with my cudgell: it
ſhall hang like a Meteor ore the Cuckolds horns: Maſter Broome, thou ſhalt know, I will predominate ouer the pezant, and thou ſhalt lye with his wife▪ Come to me ſoone at night: Ford's a knaue, and I will aggrauate his ſtile: thou (Maſter Broome) ſhalt know him for knaue, and Cuckold. Come to me ſoone at night.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: What a damn'd Epicurian-Raſcall is this? my heart is ready to cracke with impatience: who ſaies this is improuident iealouſie? my wife hath ſent to him, the howre is fixt, the match is made; would any man haue thought this? ſee the hell of hauing a faire woman: my bed ſhall be abus'd, my Coffers ranſack'd, my reputation gnawne at, and I ſhall not onely receiue this villanous wrong, but ſtand vnder the adoption of abhominable termes, and by him that does me this wrong: Termes, names: Amaimon ſounds well; Lucifer, well; Barbaſon, wel; yet they are Diuels additions, the names of fiends: But Cuckold, Wittoll, Cuckold▪ the Diuell himſelfe hath not ſuch a name. Page is an Aſſe, a ſecure Aſſe; hee will truſt his wife, hee will not bee iealous; I will rather truſt a Fleming with my butter, Perſon Hugh the Welſhman with my Cheeſe, an Iriſh man with my Aqua-vitae-bottle, or a Theefe to walke my ambling gelding, then my wife with her ſelfe. Then ſhe plots, then ſhee rumiuates▪ then ſhee deuiſes; and what they thinke in their hearts they may effect; they will breake their hearts but they will effect. Heauen bee prais'd for my iealouſie: eleuen o'clocke the howre, I will preuent this, detect my wife, bee reueng'd on Falſtaffe, and laugh at Page. I will about it, beter three houres too ſoone, then a mynute too late: fie, fie, fie: Cuckold, Cuckold, Cuckold.

div.head: Scena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Caius, Rugby, Page, Shallow, Slender, Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Iacke Rugby.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Vat lothe clocke▪ Iack.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: 'Tis paſt the howre (Sir) that Sir Hugh promis'd to meet.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: By gar, he has ſaue his ſoule, dat he is no-come: hee has pray his Pible well, dat hee is no-come, by gar (lack Rugby) he is dead already, if he be come.

sp.speaker: Rug
sp.p: Hee is wiſe Sir; hee knew your worſhip would kill him if he came.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: By gar, de herring is no dead, ſo as I vill kill him▪ take your Rapier, (Iacke) I vill tell you how I vill kill him.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: Alas ſir, I cannot fence.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Villanie, take your Rapier.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: For beare, heer's company.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: 'Bleſſe thee, bully-Doctor.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: 'Saue you Maſter Doctor Caius.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Now good Maſter Doctor.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: 'Giue you good morrow, ſir.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Vat be all you one, two, tree, fowre, come for?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: To ſee thee fight, to ſee thee foigne, to ſee thee trauerſe, to ſee thee he • re, to ſee thee there, to ſee thee paſſe thy puncto, thy ſtocke, thy reuerſe, thy diſtance, thy montant: Is hee dead, my Ethiopian? Is he dead, my Franciſco? ha Bully? what ſaies my Eſculapius? my Gallen? my heart of Elder? ha? is he dead bully-Stale? is he dead?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By gar, he is de Coward Iack-Prieſt of de vorld: he is not ſhow his face.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Thou art a Caſtalion-king Vrinall; Hector of Greece (my Boy)

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: I pray you beare witneſſe, that mee haue ſtay, ſixe or ſeuen, two tree howres for him, and hee is nocome.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: He is the wiſerman (Maſter Doctor) he is a curer of ſoules, and you a curer of bodies; if you ſhould fight, you goe againſt the haire of your profeſſions▪ is it not true, Maſter Page?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Maſter Shallow; you haue your ſelfe beene a great
great fighter, though now a man of peace.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Body-kins M. Page, though I now be old, and of the peace; if I ſee a ſword out, my finger itches to make one; though wee are Iuſtices, and Doctors, and Churchmen (Maſter Page) wee haue ſome ſalt of our youth 〈◊〉 vs, we are the ſons of women (Maſter Page.)

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: 'Tis true, Miſter Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: It will be found ſo, (M. Page) M. Doctor Caius, I am come to fetch you home, I am ſworn of the peace you haue ſhow'd your ſelfe a wiſe Phyſician, and Sir Hugh hath ſhowne himſelfe a wiſe and patient Churchman; you muſt goe with me, M. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Pardon, Gueſt-Iuſtice; a Mounſeur Mockewater.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Mock-vater? vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Mock-water, in our Engliſh tongue, is Valour (Bully.)

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By gar, then I haue as much Mock-vater as de Engliſhman; ſcuruy-lade dog-Prieſt▪ by gar, mee vill his eares.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: He will Clapper claw thee tightly (Bully.)

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Clapper de claw? vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: That is, he will make thee amends.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By gar, me doe looke he ſhall clapper-de-claw me, for by-gar me vill haue it.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: And I will prouoke him to't, or let him wag:

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Me tanck you for dat.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: And moreouer, (Bully) but firſt, Maſter Ghueſt, and M. Page, and eeke Cauale • ro Slender, goe you through the Towneto Frogmore.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: He is there, ſee what humor hee is in; and I will bring the Doctor about by the Fields; will it doe well?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Wee will doe it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Adieu, good Maſter Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By-gar, me vill kill de Prieſt, for he ſpeake for a Iackan-Ape to Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p:
Let him die; ſheath thy impatience, throw cold
water on thy Choller; goe about the fields with me through Frogmore, I will bring thee where Miſtris Anne Page is, at a Farm-houſe a Feaſting; and thou ſhalt wooe her, Cridegame, ſaid I well?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By-gar, me danck you vor dat; by gar I loue you, and I ſhall procure'a you de good Gueſt; de Earle, de Knight, de Lords▪ de Gentlemen, my patients.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: For the which, I will be thy aduerſary toward Anne Page, ſaid. I well?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By-gar, 'tis good, vell ſaid.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Let vs wag then.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Come at my heeles, Iack Rugby.

div.head: Scoena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Euans, Simple, Page, Shallow, Slender, Hoſt, Caius, Rugby.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: I pray you now, good Maſter Slenders ſeruingman and friend Simple by your name; which way haue you look'd for Maſter Caius, that calls himſelfe Doctor of Phiſicke.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Marry Sir, the pittie-ward, the Parke-ward, euery way, olde Windſor way, and euery way but the Towne-way.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: I moſt fehemently deſire you, you will looke that way.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I will ſir.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
'Pleſſe my ſoule: how full of Chollors I am and trempling of minde; I ſhall be glad if hee haue deceiued me: how melancholies I am? I will knog his Vrinalls about his knaues coſtard, when I haue good oportunities for the orke▪ Pleſſe my ſoule. To ſhallow Riuers to whoſe falls; melodious Birds ſing Madrigalls: There will wee make our Peds of Roſes: and a thouſand fragrant poſies. To ſhallow: 'Mercie on mee, I haue a great diſpoſitions to cry: Melodious birds ſing Madrigalls:—When as I ſat in Pabilon:
and a thouſand vagram Poſies. To ſhallow, &c.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Yonder he is comming, this • ay Sir Hugh.

lg.l: Hee's welcome: To ſhallow Riuers, in whoſe fals:
Heauen proſper the right: what weapons is he?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No weapons, Sir; there comes my maſter, Maſter Shallow, and another Gentleman; from Frogmore, ouer the ſtile, this way.

sp.speaker: Euen.
sp.p: Pray you giue me my gowne, or elſe keepe it in your armes.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: How now Maſter Parſon? good morrow good Sir Hugh, keepe a Gameſter from the dice, and a good Studient from his booke, and it is wonderfull.

sp.speaker: S • en.
sp.p: Ah ſweet Anne Bage.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: 'Saue you, good Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: ▪Pleaſſe you from his mercy-ſake, all of you.

lg.l: What? the Sword, and the Word?
Doe you ſtudy them both Maſter Parſon?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: And youthfull ſtill, in your doublet and hoſe, this raw-rumaticke day?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: There is reaſons, and cauſes for it?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Wee are come to you, to doe a good office, Maſter Parſon.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Fery-well, what is it?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yonder is a moſt reuerend Gentleman; who (be-like) hauing receiued wrong by ſome perſon, is at moſt odds with his owne grauity and patience, that euer you ſaw.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I haue liued foure-ſcore yeeres, and vpward; I neuer heard a man of his place, grauity, and learning, ſo wide of his owne reſpect.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: I thinke you know him; Maſter Doctor Caius the renowned French Phyſician.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Got's will, and his paſſion of my heart, I had as liefe you would tell me of a meſſe of poriedge.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Hee has no more knowledge in Hibocrates and Galen, and hee is a knaue beſides: a cowardly knaue, as
you would deſires to acquainted withall▪

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I warrant you, hee's the man ſhould fight with him.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: O ſweet Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: It appeares ſo by his weapons; keepe them a ſunder, here comes Doctor Caius.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Nay good Maſter Parſon, keepe your weapon.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: So doe you, good Maſter Doctor.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Diſarme them, and let them queſtion; let them keepe their limbs whole, and hacke our Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: I pray you let-a-mee ſpeake a word with your eare; vherefore vill you not meet a me?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: I Pray you vſe your patience in good time.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: By gar, you are de Coward: de Iacke dog: Iohn Ape.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Pray you let vs not be laughing-ſtocks to other mens humors; I deſire you in friendſhip, and I will one way or other make you amends; I will knog your Vrinal about your knaues Cogs-combe.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Diable; Iack Rugby: mine Hoſt de Iarteer; haue I not ſtay for him, to kill him? haue I not at de place I did appoint?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: As I am a Chriſtians ſoule, now looke you; this is the place appointed, ile be iudgement by mine Hoſt of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Peace, I ſay, Gallia and Gaule, French and Welch, Soule-Curer, and Body-Curer.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: I, dat is very good, excellant.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Peace, I ſay, heare mine Hoſt of the Garter, Am I politicke? Am I ſubtle? Am I a Machiuell? Shall looſe my Doctor? No, he giues me the Potions and the Motions. Shall I looſe my Parſon? my Prieſt? my Sir Hugh? No, hee giues me the Prouerbes, and the No verbes. Giue me thy hand (Celeſtiall) ſo; Boyes of Art, I haue deceiu'd you both; I haue directed you to wrong places; your hearts are mighty, your skinnes are whole, and let burn'd Sacke be the iſſue; Come▪ lay their ſwords to pawne; Follow me, Lad of peace, follow, follow, follow▪

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Truſt me, a mad Hoſt: follow Gentlemen, follow.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: O ſweet Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Ha'do I perceiue dat? Haue you make-a-de. ſot of vs, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: This is well, he has made vs his vlowting-ſtog: I deſire you that we may be friends; and let vs knog our praines together to be reuenge on this ſame ſcall ſcuruycogging-companion the Hoſt of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By gar, with all my heart; he promiſe to bring mee where is Anne Page, by gar he deceiue me too.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Well, I will ſmite his noddles; pray you follow.

div.head: Scoena Secunda.
div.stage: Miſt. Page, Robin, Ford, Page, Shallow, Slender, Hoſt, Euans, Caius.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: Nay keepe your way (little Gallant) you were wont to be a follower; but now you are a Leader: whether had you rather lead mine eyes, or eye your maſters heeles?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I had rather (forſooth, goe before you like a man▪ Courtier. then follow him like a dwarfe.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: O you are a flattering boy, now I ſee you'l be a

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well met miſtris Page, whether go you.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Truly Sir, to ſee your wife, is ſhe at home?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I, and as idle as ſhe may hang together for want of companie; I thinke if your husbands were dead, you two would marry.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Be ſure of that, two other husbands.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Where had you this pretty weather-cocke?

sp.speaker: Miſt. Pa.
sp.p: I cannot tell what (the dickens) his name is my husband had him of, what doe you cal your Knights name ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Falſtaffe.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Falſtafe.

sp.speaker: M. P.
sp.p: He, he, I can neuer hit on's name; there is ſuch aleague between my goodman, and he; is your Wife at home indeed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Indeed ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: By your leaue ſir, I am ſicke till I ſee her.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Has Page any braines▪ Hath he any eies? Hath he any thinking? Sure they ſleepe, hee hath no vſe of them: why this boy will carrie a letter twentie mile as eaſie, as a Canon will ſhoot point-blanke twelue ſcore: hee peeces out his wiues inclination, hee giues her folly motion and aduantage: and now ſhe's going to my wife, and Falſtaffes boy with her; A man may heare this ſhowre ſing in the winde; and Falſtaffes boy with her: good plots, they are laide, and our reuolted wiues ſhare damnation together. Well, I will take him, then torture my wife, plucke the borrowed vaile of modeſtie from the ſo ſeeming Miſtris Page, divulge Page himſelfe for a ſecure and wilfull Acteon, and to theſe violent proceedings all my neighbors ſhall cry aime. The clocke giues me my Qu, and my aſſurance bids me ſearch, there I ſhall finde Falſtaffe: I ſhall be rather praiſd for this, then mock'd, for it is as poſſitiue, as the earth is firme, that Falſtaffe is there: I will go.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Page, &c. Well met Maſter Ford.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Truſt me, a good knotte; I haue good cheere at home, and I pray you all go with me.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I muſt excuſe my ſelfe Maſter Ford.

lg.l: And ſo muſt I Sir,
We haue appointed to dine with Miſtris Anne,
And I would not breake with her for more mony
Then ile ſpeake of.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: We haue linger'd about a match betweene Anne Page, and my cozen Slender, and this day wee ſhall haue our anſwer.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I hope I haue your good will Father Page.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: You haue Maſter Slender, I ſtand wholly for you, But my wife (Maſter Doctor) is for you altogether.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: I be-gar, and de Maid is loue-a me: my nurſh-aQuickly tell me ſo muſh.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p:
What ſay you to young Maſter Fenton? He capers, he dances, he has cies of youth▪ he writes verſes, he ſpeakes
holliday, he ſmels Aprill and May, he will carry't, hee will carry't, 'tis in his buttons, he will carry't.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Not by my conſent I promiſe you. The Gentleman is of no hauing, he kept companie with the wilde Prince, & Pointz: hee is of too high a Region, hee knows too much: no, hee ſhall not knit a knot in his fortunes, with the finger of my ſubſtance, if he takes her, let him take her ſimply; the wealth I haue waits on my conſent, and my conſent goes not that way:

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I beſeech you heartily, ſome of you goe home with me to dinner; beſides your cheere you ſhall haue ſport, I will ſhew you a monſter; Maſter Doctor, you ſhall goe, ſo ſhall your Maſter Page, and you Sir Hugh.

lg.l: Well, fare you well:
We ſhall haue the freer woing at Maſter Pages.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Go home Iohn Rugby, I come anon.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Farwell my hearts, I will to my honeſt Knight Falſtaffe, and drinke Canarie with him.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I thinke I ſhall drinke in Pipe-wine firſt with him, ile make him dance. Will you go, Gentles?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Haue with you, to ſee this Monſter.

div.head: Scoena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Maſter Ford. Maſter Page, Seruants, Robin, Falſtaffe. Ford, Page, Caius, Euans.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: What Iohn, what Robert.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Quickly quickly; Is the Buck-basket—

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: I warrant. What Robin I ſay.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Come, come, come.

sp.speaker: Mi Ford.
sp.p: Heere, ſet it downe.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p:
Giue your men the charge, wee muſt be briefe, be ready here hard by in the Brew houſe, and when I ſodainly call you, come forth, and (without any pauſe, or ſtaggering) take this basket on your ſhoulders; that done trudge with it in all haſt, and carry it among the Whitſters
in Dotchet Mead, and there empty it in the muddie ditch, cloſe by the Thames ſide.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: You will do it?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: I ha told them ouer and ouer, they lacke no direction. Begone, and come when you are call'd.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Here comes little Robin.

sp.speaker: Miſ Ford.
sp.p: How now my Eyas Musket, what newes with you?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: My M. Sir Iohn is come in at the backe doore Miſt. Ford, and requeſts your company.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: You little lack-a-lent, haue you bin true to vs.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I, ile be ſworne; my Maſter knowes not of your being heere: and hath threatned to put mee into euerlaſting liberty, if I tell you of it; for he ſweares he'll turne me away.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Thou'rt a good boy; this ſecrecy of thine ſhall be a Tailor to thee, and ſhall make thee a new doublet and hoſe. Ile go hide me.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Do ſo, go tell thy Maſter, I am alone; Miſtris Page, remember you your Qu.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: I warrant thee, if I do not act it, hiſſe me.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford
sp.p: Go too then; we'l vſe this vnwholſome humidity, this groſſe-warry Pumpion, we'll teach him to know Turtles from Iayes.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Haue I caught thee, my heauenly Iewell? Why now let me die, for I haue liu'd long enough; This is the period of ambition; O this bleſſed houre.

sp.speaker: Miſ▪ Ford.
sp.p: O ſweet Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Miſtris Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot prate (Maſter Ford) now ſhall I ſinne in my wiſh; I would thy Husband were dead, ile ſpeake it before the beſt Lord, I would make thee my Lady.

sp.speaker: Miſ Ford.
sp.p: I your Lady Sir Iohn? Alas, I ſhould be a pittifull Lady.

sp.speaker: Fal▪
sp.p: Let the Court of France ſhew mee ſuch another; I ſee how thine eye would emulate the Diamond; Thou haſt the right arched-beauty of the brow, that becomes the Ship-tyre, the Tyre-valiant, or any Tire of Venetian admittance.

lg.l: A plaine Kerchiefe, Sir Iohn.
My browes become nothing elſe, nor that well neither.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thou art a tyrant to ſay ſo: thou wouldſt make an abſolute Courtier, and the firme fixture of thy foote, would giue an excellent motion to thy gate, in a ſemicircled Farthingale. I ſee what thou wert if Fortune thy foe, were not Noture thy friend: Come, thou canſt not hide it.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: Beleeue me, ther's no ſuch thing in me.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What made me loue thee? Let that perſwade thee: Ther's ſomething extraordinary in thee. Come I cannot cog, and ſay thou art this and that, like a manie of theſs liſping hauthorne buds, that come like women in mens apparrell, and ſmell like. Bucklers-berry in ſimple time: I cannot, but I loue thee, none but thee; and thou deſeru'ſt it.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Do not betray me ſir, I feare you loue M. Page▪

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thou mightſt as well ſay, I loue to walke by the Counter-gate, which is a hatefull to me, as the reeke of a Lime-kill.

lg.l: Well, heauen knowes how I loue you,
And you ſhall one day finde it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Keepe in that minde, Ile deſerue it.

lg.l: Nay, I muſt tell you, ſo you doe;
Or elſe I could not be in that minde.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Miſtris Ford, Miſtris Ford, heere's Miſtris Page at the doore, ſweating, and blowing, and looking wildly, and would needs ſpeake with you preſently.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: She ſhall not ſee me, I will enſconce mee behinde the Arras.

lg.l: Pray you doe ſo, ſhe's a very tatling woman.
Whats the matter? How now?
O miſtris Ford what haue you done?
You'r ſham'd, y'are ouerthrowne, y'are vndone for euer.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: What's the matter, good miſtris Page?

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: O weladay, miſt. Ford, hauing and honeſtman to your husband, to giue him ſuch cauſe of ſuſpition.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: What cauſe of ſuſpition?

lg.l: What cauſe of ſuſpition? Out vpon you:
How am I miſtooke in you?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Why (alas) what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Your husband's comming hether (Woman) with all the Officers in Windſor, to ſearch for a Gentleman, that hee ſayes is heere now in the houſe, by your conſent to take an ill aduantage of his abſence, you are vndone.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: 'Tis not, ſo, I hope.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: Pray heauen it be not ſo, that you haue ſuch a man heere: but 'tis moſt certaine your husband's comming, with halfe Windſor at his heeles, to ſerch for ſuch a one, I come before to tell you, if you know your ſelfe cleere, why I am glad of it, but if you haue a friend here, conuey, conuey him out. Be not amaz'd, call all your ſenſes to you, defend your reputation, or bid farwell to your good life for euer.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: What ſhall I doe? There is a Gentleman my deere friend, and I feare not mine owne ſhame ſo much, as his perill. I had rather then a thouſand pound he were out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: For ſhame, neuer ſtand (you had rather, you had rather) your husband's heere at hand, bethinke you of ſome conueyance: in the houſe you cannot bide him. Oh, how haue you deceiu'd me? Looke, heere is a basket, if hee be of any reaſonable ſtature, hee may creepe in heere, and throw fowle linnen vpon him, as if it were going to bucking; Or it is whiting time, ſend him by your two men to Datchet-Meade.

sp.speaker: M. Ford
sp.p: He's too big to go in there, what ſhall I doe?

lg.l: Let me ſee't, let me ſee't, O let me ſee't:
Ile • n ile in, follow your friends counſell, ile in.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: What Sir Iohn Falſtaffe? Are theſe your Letters Knight?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I loue thee, helpe mee away: let me creepe in heere: ile neuer—

sp.speaker: M. Page.
