sp.p: Helpe to couer your Maſter (Boy:) Call your men (Miſt. Ford.) You diſſembling Knight.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: What Iohn Rugby, Iohn; Goe, take vp theſe cloathes heere, quickly: Wher's the Cowle-ſtaffe? Looke how you drumble? Carry them to the Landreſſe in Datchet meade: quickly▪ come.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: 'Pray you come neere; if I ſuſpect without cauſe, Why then make ſport at me, then let me be your ieſt, I deſerue it: How now? Whether beare you this?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: To the Landreſſe forſooth?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Why, what haue you to doe whether they beare it? You were beſt meddle with buck-waſhing.

sp.speaker: Ford.

lg.l: Bucke? I would I could waſh my ſelfe of the Buck:
Bucke, bucke, bucke, I bucke; I warrant you Bucke,
And of the ſeaſon too, it ſhall appeare.

sp.p: Gentlemen, I haue dream'd to night, ile tell you my dreame, heere, heere, heere bee my keyes, aſcend my Chambers, ſearch, ſeeke, finde out: ile warrant wee'le vnkennell the Fox. Let mee ſtop this way firſt: ſo, now vncape.

lg.l: Good maſter Ford, be contented:
You wrong your ſelfe too much.
True (maſter Page) vp Gentlemen,
You ſhall ſee ſport anon:
Follow me Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: This is fery fantaſticall humors and iealouſies.

lg.l: By gar, 'tis no-the faſhion of France:
It is not iealous in France.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Nay follow him (Gentlemen) ſee the yſſue of his ſearch.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Is there not a double excellency in this?

lg.l: I know not which pleaſes me better,
That my husband is deceiued, or Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: What a taking was he in, when your husband askt who was in the basket?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: I am halfe affraid hee will haue neede of waſhing, ſo throwing him into the water, will doe him a benefit.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Hang him diſhoneſt raſcall: I would all of the ſame ſtraine, were in the ſame diſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: I thinke my husband hath ſome ſpeciall ſuſpition of Falſtafs being heere: for I neuer ſaw him ſo groſſe in his iealouſie till now.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: I will lay a plot to try that, and wee will yet haue more trickes with Falſtaffe; his diſſolute diſeaſe will ſcarſe obey this medicne.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Shall we ſend that fooliſhion Carion, Miſtris Quickly to him, and excuſe his throwing into the water, and giue him another hope, to betray him to another puniſhment?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Wee will doe it; let him be ſent for to morrow eight a clocke to haue amends.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I cannot finde him; may be the knaue bragg'd of that he could not compaſſe▪

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Heard you that?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: You vſe me well, M Ford? Doe you?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I, I doe ſo.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Heauen make you better then your thoughts

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: You doe your ſelfe mighty wrong (M. Ford)

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I, I; I muſt beare it.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: If there be any pody in the houſe, and in the chambers, and in the coffers, and in the preſſes; heauen forgiue my ſinnes at the day of iudgement.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Be-gar, nor I too: there is no bodies.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Fy, fy, M Ford, are you not aſham'd? What ſpirit, what diuell ſuggeſts this imagination? I would not ha your diſtemper in this kind, for the welth of Windſor caſtle.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: 'Tis my fault (M. Page) I ſuffer for it.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: You ſuffer for a pad conſcience; your wife is as honeſt a o'mans, as I will deſires among fiue thouſand, and fiue hundred too.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By gar, I ſee 'tis an honeſt woman.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well, I promiſd you a dinner, come, come, walke in the Parke, I pray you pardon me: I will hereafter make knowne to you why I haue done this. Come wife, come Miſt Page, I pray you pardon me. Pray hartly pardon me.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Let's go in Gentlemen, but (truſt me) we'l mocke
him; I doe inuite you to morrow morning to my houſe to breakefaſt: after we'll a Birding together, I haue a fine Hawke for the buſh. Shall it be ſo:

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: If there is one, I ſhall make two in the Companie.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: If there be one, or two, I ſhall make-a-theturd.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Pray you goe, M. Page.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: I pray you now remembrance to morrow on the lowſie knaue, mine Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Dat is good by gar, withall my heart.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: A lowſie knaue, to haue his gibes, and his mockeries.

div.head: Scoena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Fenton, Anne Page, Shallow, Slender, Quickly, Page, Miſt. Page.

lg.l: I ſee I cannot get thy Fathers loue,
Therefore no more turne me to him (ſweet Nan.)

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Alas, how then?

lg.l: Why thou muſt be thy ſelfe.
He doth obiect, I am too great of birth,
And that my ſtate being gall'd with my expence,
I ſeeke to heale it onely by his wealth.
Beſides theſe, other barres he layes before me,
My Riots paſt, my wilde Societies,
And tels me 'tis a thing impoſſible
I ſhould loue thee, but as a property.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: May be he tels you true.

lg.l: No, heauen ſo ſpeed me in my time to come,
Albeit I will confeſſe, thy Fathers wealth
Was the firſt motiue that I woo'd thee (Anne:)
Yet wooing thee, I found thee of more valew
Then ſtamps in Gold, or ſummes in ſealed bagges •
And 'tis the very riches of thy ſelfe,
That now I ayme at.
Gentle M. Fenton.
Yet ſeeke my Fathers loue, ſtill ſeeke it ſir,
If opportunity and humbleſt ſuite
Cannot attaine it, why then harke you hither.
Breake their talke Miſtris Quickly,
My Kinſman ſhall ſpeake for himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ile make a ſhaft or a bolt on't, ſlid, tis but venturing.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Be not diſmaid.

lg.l: No, ſhe ſhall not diſmay me▪
I care not for that, but that I am affeard.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Hark ye, Maſter Slender would ſpeake a word with you

lg.l: I come to him. This is my Fathers choice.
O what a world of vilde-ill-fauour'd faults
Lookes handſome in three hundred pounds a yeare?
And how do's god Maſter Fenton?
Pray you a word with you.
Shee's comming; to her Coz:
O boy, thou hadſt a father,

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I had a father (Miſtris Anne) my vncle can tel you good ieſts of him; pray you Vncle, tel Miſtris Anne the ieſt how my Father ſtole two Geeſe out of a Pen, good Vnckle.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Miſtris Anne, my Cozen loues you.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I that I doe, as well as I loue any woman in Gloceſterſhire.

sp.speaker: Shal
sp.p: He will maintaine you like a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I that I will, come cut and long-taile, vnder the degree of a Squire.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Hee will make you a handred and fiftie pounds ioynture.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Good Maſter Shallow let him woe for himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Marry I thanke you for it, I thanke you for that good comfort: ſhe cals you (Coz) ile leaue you.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Now Maſter Slender.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Now good Miſtris Anne.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: What is your will?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: My will? Odd's-hart-lings, that's a prettie ieſt indeed: I ne're made my Will yet (I thanke Heauen:) I am not ſuch a ſickely creature, I giue Heauen praiſe.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: I meane (M. Sender) what would you with me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Truely, for mine owne part, I would little or nothing with you: your father and vncle hath made motions if it be my lucke, ſo; if not, happy man be his dole, they can tell you how things goe, better then I can: you may, your father, heere he comes.

lg.l: Now Maſter Slender; Loue him daughter Anne.
Why how now? What does Maſter Fenton here?
You wrong me Sir, thus ſtill to haunt my houſe.
I told you Sir, my daughter is diſpoſd of.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Nay Maſter Page, be not impatient.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: Good Maſter Fenton. come not to my child.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: She is no match for you.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Sir, will you heare me?

lg.l: No, good Maſter Fenton.
Come M. Shallow: Come ſonne Slender, in;
Knowing my minde, vou wrong me (M. Fenton.)

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Speake to Miſtris Page.

lg.l: Good Miſtris Page, for that I loue your daughter
In ſuch a righteous faſhion as I do,
Perforce, againſt all checkes, rebukes, and manners,
I muſt aduance the colours or my loue,
And not retire. Let me haue your good will.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Good mother, do not marry me to yond foole:

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: I meane it not, I ſeeke you a better huſband.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: That's my maſter, Maſter Doctor.

lg.l: Alas I had rather be ſet quicki'th earth,
And bowl'd to death with Turnips.
Come, trouble not your ſelfe good Maſter
Fenton, I will not be your friend, nor enemy:
My daughter will I queſtion how ſhe loues you,
And as I finde her, ſo am I affected;
Till then, farewill Sir, ſhe muſt needs go in,
Her father will be angry.

sp.speaker: Fen
sp.p: Farewell gentle Miſtris; farewell Nan.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: This is my doing now; Nay, ſaine I, will you caſt away your childe on a Foole, and a Phyſitian:
Looke on Maſter Fenton, this is my doing.

lg.l: I thanke thee: and I pray thee once to night,
Giue my ſweet Nan this Ring: there's for thy paines:

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Now heauen ſend thee good fortune, a kinde heart he hath: a woman would run through fire and water for ſuch a kinde heart. But yet, I would my Maſter had Miſtris Anne, or I would Maſter Slender had her: or (in ſooth) I would Maſter Fenton had her; I will doe what I can for them all three, for ſo I haue promiſed, and ile be as good as my word, but ſpeciouſly for Maſter Fenton. Well, I muſt of another errand to Sir Iohn Falſtaffe from my two Miſtreſſes: what a beaſt am I to ſlacke it.

div.head: Scoena Quarta▪
div.stage: Enter Falſtaffe, Bardolfe, Quickly, Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Bardolfe I ſay.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Heere Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Go, fetch me a quart of Sacke, put a toſt in't. Haue I liu'd to be carried in a Basket like a barrow of butchers Offall? and to be throwne in the Thames? Wel, if I be ſeru'd ſuch another tricke, ile haue my braines 'tane out and butter'd, and giuen them to a dogge for a New-yeares gift: The rogues ſlighted mee into the Riuer with as little remorſe, as they would haue drown'de ablinde bitches Puppies, fifteene i'th litter: and you may know by my ſize, that I haue a kinde of alacrity in ſinking: if the bottome were as deepe as hell, I ſhould downe. I had beene drown'd, but that the ſhore was ſheluy and ſhallow; a death that I abhorre: for the water ſwelles a man; and what a thing ſhould I haue beene, when I had beene ſwel'd? I ſhould haue beene a Mountaine of Mummie.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Here's M. Quickly Sir to ſpeake with you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Come, let me poure in ſome Sacke to the Thames water: for my bellies as cold as if I had ſwallow'd ſnowbals, for pilles to coole the reines. Call her in.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Come in woman.

lg.l: By your leaue; I cry you mercy?
Giue your worſhip good morrow.
Take away theſe Challices;
Go, brew me a pottle of Sacke finely.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: With Egges, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Simple of it ſelfe; Ile no Pullet-Sperſme in my brewage. How now?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Marry Sir, I come to your worſhip from M. Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Miſ. Ford? I haue had Ford enough; I was thrown into the Ford, I haue my belly full of Ford.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Alas the day, (good-heart) that was not her fault; ſhe do's ſo take on with her men; they miſtooke their promise▪ erection.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: So did I mine, to build vpon a fooliſh Womans

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Well, ſhe laments Sir for it, that it would yern your heart to ſee it; her husband goes this morning a birding; ſhe deſires you once more to come to her, betweene eight and nine; I muſt carry her word quickely, ſhe'll make you amends I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, I will viſit her, tell her ſo▪ and bidde her thinke what a man is; Let her conſider his frailety, and then iudge of my merit.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: I will tell her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Do ſo. Betweene nine and ten ſaiſt thou?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Eight and nine Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, be gone; I will not miſſe her.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Peace be with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I meruaile I heare not of Maſter Broome; he ſent me word to ſtay within; I like his money well: Oh, heere he comes.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Bleſſe you Sir.

lg.l: Now M. Broome, you come to know
What hath paſt betweene me, and Fords wife.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: That indeed (Sir Iohn) is my buſineſſe.

lg.l: M. Broome I will not lye to you,
I was at her houſe the houre ſhe appointed me.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And ſped you Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Very ill fauouredly M. Broome.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: How ſo ſir, did ſhe change her determination?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No (M. Broome) but the peaking Curnuio her huſband (M. Broome) dwelling in a continnall larum of ielouſie, comes me in the inſtant of our encounter, after wee had embraſt, kiſt, proteſted, and (as it were) ſpoke the prologue of our Comedy▪ and at his heeles, a rabble of his companions, thither prouoked and inſtigated by his diſtemper, and (forſooth) to ſearch his houſe for his wiues Loue.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: What? While you were there?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: While I was there.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And did he ſearch for you, and could not find you?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You ſhall heare. As good lucke would haue it, comes in one Miſt. Page, giues intelligence of Fords approach: and in her inuention, and Fords wiues diſtraction, they conuey'd me into a bucke-basket.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: A Buck-basket?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Yes, a Buck-basket: ram'd mee in with foule Shirts, and Smockes, Socks, foule Stockings, greaſie Napkins, that (Maſter Broome) there was the rankeſt compound of villanous ſmell, that euer offended noſtrill.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And how long lay you there?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Nay, you ſhall heare (Maſter Broome) what I haue ſuffered, to bring this woman to euill, for your good: Being thus cram'd in the Basket, • couple of Fords knaues, his Hindes, were cald forth by their Miſtris, to carry mee in the name of foule Cloathes to Datchet lane; they tooke mee on their ſhoulders met the iealous knaue their Maſter in the doore; who asked them once or twice what they had in their Baſket? I quak'd for feare leſt the Lunatique Knaue would haue ſearch'd it: but Fate (ordaining hee ſhould bee a Cuckold) held his hand: well, on went hee, for
a ſearch and away went I for foule Cloathes; But marke the ſequell (Maſter Broome) I ſuffered the pangs of three ſeuerall deaths: Firſt, an intollerable fright, to bee detected with a iealious rotten Bell▪ weather: Next to bee compaſs'd like a good Bilbo in the circumference of a Pecke, hilt to point, heele to▪ head. And then to bee ſtopt in like a ſtrong diſtillation with ſtinking Cloathes, that fretted in their owne greaſe thinke of that, a man of my Kidney; thinke of that; that am as ſubiect to heate as butter; a man of continuall diſſolution, and thaw: it was a miracle to ſcapeſuffocation. And in the height of this Bath (when I was more then halfe ſtew'd in greaſe (like a Dutchdiſh) to bee throwne into the Thames, and coold, glowing hot, in that ſerge like a Horſeſhoo; thinke of that; hiſſing hot: thinke of that (Maſter Broome.)

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: In good ſadneſſe Sir, I am ſorry, that for my ſake you haue ſufferd all this.
My ſuite then is deſperate: You'll vndertake her no more?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Maſter Broome: I will bee throwne into E • ta, as I haue beene into Thames, ere I will leaue her thus; her Husband is this morning gone a Birding, I haue receiued from her another ambaſſie of meeting; 'twixt eight and nine is the houre (Maſter Broome.)

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: 'Tis paſt eight already Sir,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Is it? I will then addreſſe mee to my appointment; Come to mee at your conuenient leaſure, and you ſhall know how I ſpeede: and the concluſion ſhall bee crowned with your enioying her: adiew; you ſhall haue her (Maſter Broome) Maſter Broome, you ſhal cuckold Ford.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Hum: ha? Is this a viſion? Is this a dreame? doe I ſleepe? Maſter Ferd awake, awake Maſter Ford▪
ther's a hole made in your beſt coate (Maſter Ford:) this 'tis to bee marryed; this 'tis to haue Lynnen, and Buckbaskets: Well, I will proclaime my ſelfe what I am▪ I will now take the Leacher; hee is at my houſe; hee cannot ſcape mee; 'tis impoſſible hee ſhould: hee cannot creepe into a halfe-penny purſe, not into a Pepper-Boxe. But leſt the Diuell that guides him, ſhould aide him, I will ſearch impoſſible places: though what I am, I cannot auoide; yet to bee what I would not, ſhall not make me tame; If I haue hornes, to make one mad, let the prouerbe goe with mee, ile bee hornemad.

div.head: Scoena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Miſtris Page, Quickly, William, Euens:

sp.speaker: Miſ Page.
sp.p: Is he at M. Fords already think'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Sure hee is by this; or will bee preſently; but truely hee is very couragious mad, about his throwing into the water. Miſtris Ford deſires you to come ſodainely.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Ile be with her by and by; ile but bring my yong-man here to Schoole; looke where his Maſter comes; 'tis a playing day I ſee: how now Sir Hugh, no Schoole to day?

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: No, Maſter Slender is let the Boyes leaue to play.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: 'Bleſſing of his heart.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Sir Hugh, my husband ſaies my ſonne profits nothing in the world at his Booke; I pray you aske him ſome queſtions in his Accidence.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: Come hither William; hold vp your head; come.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Come-on Sirha; hold vp your head; anſwere your Maſter, be not afraid.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: William, how many Numbers is in Nownes?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Two.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Truely, I thought there had bin one Number more, becauſe they ſay od's-Nownes.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Peace, your tatlings. What is (Faire) William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Pulcher.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Powlcats? there are fairer things then Powlcat, ſure.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: You are a very ſimplicity o'man; I pray you peace. What is (Lapis) William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A Stone.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: And what is a Stone (William?)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A Peeble.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: No; it is Lapis; I pray you remember in your praine.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Lapis.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: That is a good William; what is he (William) that do's lend Articles:

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Articles are borrowed of the Pronoune; and be thus declined▪ Singulariter nominatiuo hic haec, hoc.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Nominatiuo hig, hag, hog; pray you marke; genitiue huius; Well: what is your Accuſatiue-caſe?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Accuſatiue hinc.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: I pray you haue your remembrance (childe) Accuſatiuo hing, hang, hog.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Hang-hog, is latten for Bacon, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Leaue your prables (o'man) What is the Focatiue caſe (William?)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: O, Vocatiuo, O.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Remember William, Focatiue, is caret:

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: And that's a good roote.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: O'man, forbare.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: What is your Genitiue caſe plurall (William?)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Genitiue caſe?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Genitiue horum, harum, horum.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Vengeance of Ginyes caſe; fie on her; neuer name
her (childe) if ſhe be a whore.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: For ſhame o'man.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: You doe ill to teach the childe ſuch words: hee teaches him to hic, and to hac; which they'll doe faſt enough of themſelues, and to call horum; fie vpon you.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: O'man, art thou Lunaties? Haſt thou no vnderſtandings for thy Caſes, and the numbers of the Genders? Thou art as fooliſh Chriſtian creatures, as I would deſires.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Pre'thee hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Shew me now (William) ſome declenſions of your Pronounes.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Forſooth, I haue forgot.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: It is Qui, que, quod; if you forget your Quies, your Ques, and your Quods, you muſt be preeches: Goe your waies and play, go.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: He is a better ſcholler then I thought hee was.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: He is a good ſprag▪ memory: Farewel Mis. Page.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Adeu good Sir Hugh.
Get you home boy, Come we ſtay too long.

div.head: Scoena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Falſtaffe, M. Ford, Miſt. Page. Seruants, Ford, Page, Caius, Euans Shallow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Miſ. Ford, Your ſorrow hath eaten vp my ſufferance; I ſee you are obſequious in your loue, and I profeſſe requitall to a haires bredth, not onely Miſtris Ford, in the ſimple office of loue, but in all the accuſtrement complement, and ceremony of it: But are you ſure of your husband now?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Hee's a birding (ſweet Sir Iohn.)

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: What hoa▪ goſſip Ford; what hoa.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Step into th' chamber, Sir Iohn▪

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p:
How now (ſweet heart) whoſe at home▪
beſides your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Miſ Ford.
sp.p: Why none but mine owne people.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Frod.
sp.p: No certainly; Speake louder.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Truly, I am ſo glad you haue no body here.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Why woman, your husband is in his olde lines againe; he ſo takes on yonder with my husband, ſo railes againſt all married mankind; ſo curſes all Eues daughters, of what complexion ſoeuer; and ſo buffettes himſelfe on the for-head; crying peere-out, peere-out, that any madneſſe I euer yet beheld, ſeem'd but tameneſſe, ciuility, and patience to this his diſtemper he is in now. I am glad the fat Knight is not heere,

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Why, do's he talke of him?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Of none but him, and ſweares hee was caried out the laſt time hee ſearch'd for him, in a Basket; Proteſts to my husband he is now heere, and hath drawne him and the reſt of their company from their ſport, to make another experiment of his ſuſpition: But I am glad the Knight is not heere; now hee ſhall ſee his owne foolerie.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: How neere is he Miſtrs Page?

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: Hard by, at ſtreet end; he will be here anon▪

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: I am vndone, the Knight is heere:

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: Why then you are vtterly ſham'd, and hee's but a dead man. What a woman are you? Away with him, away with him; Better ſhame, then murther.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: Which way ſhould he goe? How ſhould I beſtow him? Shall I put him into the basket againe?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No, Ile come no more i'th Basket.
May I not goe out ere he come?

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: Alas: three of Maſter Fords brothers watch the doore with Piſtols, that none ſhall iſſue out: otherwiſe you might ſlip away ere hee came: But what make you heere?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What ſhall I doe? Ile creepe vp into the chimney.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: There they alwayes vſe to diſcharge their Birding-peece: creepe into the Kill▪hole.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Hee will ſeeke there on my word; Neyther Preſſe, Coffer, Cheſt, Trunke, Well, Vault, but hee hath an abſtract for the remembrance of ſuch places, and goes to them by his Note; There is no hiding you in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ile goe out then:

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: If you goe out in your owne ſemblance, you die Sir Iohn, vnleſſe you go out diſguis'd.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: How might we diſguiſe him?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Alas the day I know not, there is no womans gowne bigge enough for him: otherwiſe he Might put on a hat, a muffler, and kerchiefe, and ſo eſcape.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good hearts, diuiſe ſomething; any extremitie, rather then a miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: My Maids Aunt the fat woman of Brainford, has a gowne aboue.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: On my word it will ſerue him: ſhee's as big as he is; and there's her thrum'd hat, and her muffler▪ too: run vp Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Go, go, ſweet Sir Iohn: Miſtris Page and I will looke ſome linnen for your head.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Quicke, quicke, wee'le come dreſſe you ſtraight: put on the gowne the while.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: I would my husband would meete him in this ſhape; he cannot abide the old woman of Brainford; hee ſweares ſhe's a witch, forbad her my houſe, and hath threatned to beate her.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Heauen guide him to thy husbands cudgell; and the diuell guide his cudgell afterwards.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: But is my husband comming?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: I in good ſadneſſe is hee, and talkes of the basket too, howſoeuer he hath had intelligence.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Wee'l try that: for ile appoint my men to carry the basket againe, to meete him at the doore with it, as they did laſt time.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: Nay, but hee'l be heere preſently: let goe dreſſe him like the witch of Brainford.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: Ile firſt direct my men, what they ſhall doe with the basket: Goe vp, ile bring linnen for him ſtraight.

lg.l: Hang him diſhonſt Varlet,
We cannot miſuſe enough:
Well leaue a proofe by that which we will doe,
Wiues may be merry, and yet honeſt too:
We do not acte that often, ieſt, and laugh,
'Tis old, but true, Still Swine eats all the draugh.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: Go Sirs, take the bas basket againe on your ſhoulders: your Maſter is hard at doore: if he bid you ſet it downe, obey him▪ quickly, diſpatch.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Come, come, take it vp.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Pray heauen it be not full of Knight againe.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: I hope not, I had liefe as beare ſo much lead.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I, but if it proue true (Maſter Page) haue you any way then to vnfoole mee againe. Set downe the basket villaine: ſome body call my wife: Youth in a basket: Oh you Panderly Raſcals, there's a knot: a gin, a packe, a conſpiracie againſt mee. Now ſhall the diuel be ſham'd-What wiſe I ſay: Come, come forth: behold what honeſt cloathes you ſend forth to bleaching.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Why, this paſſes Maſter Ford, you are not to goe looſe any longer, you muſt be pinnion'd.

sp.speaker: Euan • :
sp.p: Why, this is Lunaticks: this is madde, as a mad dogge.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: In deed Maſter Ford, this is not well indeed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: So ſay I too Sir, come hither Miſtris Ford, Miſtris Ford, the honeſt woman, the modeſt wife, the vertuous creature▪ that hath the iealous foole to her husband: I ſuſpect without cauſe (Miſtris) do I?

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: Heauen be my witneſſe you do, if you ſuſpect me in any diſhoneſty.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well ſaid Brazen-face, hold it out: Come forth ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: This paſſes.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: Are you not a ſham'd, let the cloths alone.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I ſhall finde you anon.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: 'Tis vnreaſonable; will you take vp your wiues cloathes? Come, away.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Empty the basket I ſay.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Why man, why?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Maſter Page, as I am a man, there was one conuay'd out of my houſe yeſterday in this basket: why may not he be there againe, in my houſe I am ſure hee is; my Intelligence is true, my iealouſie is reaſonable, plucke mee out all the linnen.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: If you find a man there, hee ſhall dye a Fleas death.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Heer's no man.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: By my fidelity this is not well Maſter Ford: This wrongs you.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: Maſter Ford, you muſt pray, and not follow the imaginations of your owne heart: this is iealouſies.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well, hee's not heere I ſeeke for.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: No, nor no where elſe but in your braine.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Helpe to ſearch my houſe this one time: if I find not what I ſeeke, ſhew no colour for my extremity; Let me for euer be your Table-ſport; Let them ſay of me, as iealous as Ford, that ſearch'd a hollow Wall-nut for his wiues Lemman. Satisfie me once more, once more ſerch with me.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: What hoa (Miſtris Page,) come you and the old woman downe; my husband will come into the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Old woman? what old womans that?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Why it is my maids Aunt of Brainford.

sp.speaker: Ford:
sp.p: A witch, a Queane, an olde couzening queane: Haue I not forbid her my houſe. She comes of errands, do's ſhe? We are ſimple men, wee doe not know what's brought to paſſe vnder the profeſſion of Fortune telling, She workes by Charmes, by Spels, by th' Figure, and ſuch dawbry as this is, beyond our Element: wee know nothing. Come downe you Witch, you Hagge you, come downe I ſay.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Nay, good ſweet husband, good Gentlemen, let him not ſtrike the old woman.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Come mother Prat, Come giue me your hand.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Ile Prat-her: Out of my doore, you Witch, you Hagge, you Baggage, you Poulcat, you Runnion, out, out: Ile coniure you, ile fortune tell you.

lg.l: Are you not a ſham'd?
I thinke you haue kill'd the poore woman.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Nay hee will do it, 'tis a goodly credit for you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Hang her witch.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: By yea, and no, I thinke the o'man is a witch indeede: I like not when a o'mans has a great peard; I ſpie a great peard vnder his muffler.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Will you follow Gentlemen, I beſeech you follow; ſee but the iſſue of my iealouſie. If I cry out thus vpon no traile, neuer truſt me when I open againe.

lg.l: Let's obey his humour a little further;
Come Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Truſt me he beate him moſt pittifully.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Nay by th' Maſſe that he did not; he beate him moſt vnpittifully, me thought.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Ile haue the cudgell hallow'd, and hung ore the Altar, it hath done meritorious ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: What thinke you? May wee with the warrant of woman-hood, and the witneſſe of a good conſcience, purſue him with any further reuenge?

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: The ſpirit of wantonneſſe is ſure ſcar'd out of him, if the diuell haue him not in fee-ſimple, with find & recouery, he will neuer (I thinke) in the way of waſte, attempt vs againe.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: Shall wee tell our husbands how wee haue ſeru'd him?

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: Yes, by all meanes: if it be but to ſcrape the figures out of your husbands braines: if they can find in their hearts, the poore vnuertuous fat Knight ſhall be any further afflicted, wee two will bee ſtill the miniſters.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Ford.
sp.p: Ile warrant, they'l haue him publiquely ſham'd, and me thinkes there would be no period to ieſt, ſhould he not be publikely ſham'd.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: Come, to the Forge with it, then ſhape it: I would not haue things coole.

div.head: Scoena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Hoſt and Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Sir, the Germane deſires to haue three of your horſes: the Duke himſelfe will be to morrow at Court, and they are going to meet him.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: What Duke ſhould that be comes ſo ſecretly? I heare not of him in the Court: let me ſpeake with the Gentlemen, they ſpeake Engliſh?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I Sir, Ile call him to you.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: They ſhall haue my horſes, but Ile make them pay: Ile ſauce them, they haue had my houſes a weeke at commaund. I haue turn'd away my other gueſts they muſt come off, Ile ſawce them, come.

div.head: Scoena Quarta▪
div.stage: Enter Page, Ford, Miſtris. Page, Miſtris Ford, and Euans.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: 'Tis one of the beſt diſcretions of a o'mans as euer I did looke vpon.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: And did he ſend you both theſe Letters at an inſtant?

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: Within a quarter of an houre.

lg.l: Pardon me (wife) henceforth doe what thou wilt:
I rather will ſuſpect the Sunne with gold,
Then thee with wantonnes: Now doth thy honor ſtand
(In him that was of late an Heretike)
As firme as faith.
'Tis well, 'tis well, no more:
Be not as extreme in ſubmiſſion, as in offence,
But let our plot go forward: Let our wiues
Yet once againe (to make vs publike ſport)
Appoint a meeting with this old fat-fellow,
Where we may take him, and diſgrace him for it.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: There is no better way then that they ſpoke of.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: How? to ſend him word they'll meete him in the Parke at midnight? Fie, fie, he'll neuer come.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: You ſay he has bin throwne in the Riuers: and has bin greeuouſly peaten, as an old o'man: me-thinkes there ſhould be terror in him, that hee ſhould not come: Me-thinkes his fleſh is puniſh'd, hee ſhall haue no deſires,

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: So thinke I too.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Deuiſe but how you'l vſe him when he comes, And let vs two deuiſe to bring him thither.

lg.l: There is an old tale goes, that Herne the
Hunter (ſometime a keeper heere in Windſor Forreſt)
Doth all the winter time, at ſtill midnight,
Walke round about an Oake, with great rag'd hornes,
And there he blaſts the tree, and takes the cattle,
And make milch-kine yeeld blood, and ſhakes a chaine
In a moſt hideous and dredfull manner.
You haue heard of ſuch a Spirit, and well you know
The ſuperſtitious idle-headed-Eld
Receiu'd, and did deliuer to our age
This tale of Herne the Hunter, for a truth.
Why yet there want not many that do feare
In deepe of night to walke by this Hernes Oake:
But what of this?
Marry this is our deuiſe,
That Falſtaffe at that Oake ſhall meete with vs.
Well, let it not be doubted but he'll come,
And in this ſhape, when you haue brought him thether,
What ſhall be done with him? What is your plot?
That likewiſe haue we thoght vpon and thus:
Nan Page (my daughter) and my little ſonne,
And three or foure more of their growth, wee'l dreſſe
Like Vrchins, Ouphes, and Fairies, greene and white,
With rounds of waxen Tapers on their heads
And rattles in their hands; vpon a ſodaine,
As Falſtaffe, and I, are newly met,
Let them from forth a ſaw▪ pitruſh at once
With ſome diffuſed ſong: Vpon their ſight
We two, in great amazedneſſe will flye:
Then let them all encircle him about,
And Fairy-like to pinch the vncleane Knight;
And aske him why that houre of Fairy Reuell,
In their ſo ſacred pathes, he dares to tread
In ſhape prophane.
And till he tell the truth,
Let the ſuppoſed Fairies pinch him, ſound,
And burne him with their Tapers.
The truth being knowne.
We'll all preſent our ſelues; diſ-horne the ſpirit,
And mocke him home to Windſor.
The children muſt
Be practis'd well to this, or they'll neu'r doo't.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: I will teach the children their behauiours & I will: be like a Iacke-an-Apes alſo, to burne the Knight with my Taber.

lg.l: That will be excellent,
Ile go buy them vizards.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: My Nan ſhall be the Queene of all the Fairies, finely attired in a robe of white.

lg.l: That ſilke will I go buy, and in that time
Shall M. Slender ſteale my Nan away,
And marry her at Eaton: go, ſend to Falſtaffe ſtraight.
Nay. Ile to him againe in the name of Broome,
Hee'l tell me all his purpoſe: ſure hee'l come.
Feare not you that; Go get vs properties
And tricking for our Fayries.
Let vs about it,
It is admirable pleaſures, and ferry honeſt knaueries.
Go Miſ. Ford,
Send quickly to Sir Iohn, to know his minde;
Ile to the Doctor, he hath my good will,
And none but he to marry with Nan Page;
That Slender (though well landed) is an Ideot,
And he, my husband beſt of all affects;
The Doctor is well monied and friends
Potent at Court; he, none but he ſhall haue her,
Though twenty thouſand worthier come to craue her.

div.head: Scoena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Hoſt, Simple, Falſtaffe, Bardolfe, Euans, Cains, Quickly.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What wouldſt thou haue? (Boore) what? (thick skin) ſpeake, breathe, diſcuſſe; breefe, ſhort, quicke, nap.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Marry Sir, I come to ſpeake with Sir Iohn Falſtaffe from Maſter Slender.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: There's his Chamber, his Houſe, his Caſtle his ſtanding bed and truckle-bed: 'tis painted about with the ſtory of the Prodigall, freſh and new: goe, knocke and call: hee'l ſpeake like an Anthropophaginian vnto thee; Knocke I ſay.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: There's an olde woman, a fat woman gone vp into his chamber; ile be ſo bold as ſtay Sir till ſhe come down I come to ſpeake with her indeed.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Ha▪ A fat woman? The Knight may be robb'd; Ile call. Bully-Knight, Bully Sir Iohn; ſpeake from thy Lungs Military; Art thou there? It is thine Hoſt, thine Epheſian cals.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How now mine Hoſt?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Here's a Bohemian-Tartar taries the comming downe of thy fat-woman. Let her deſcend (Bully) let her deſcend▪ my Chambers are honourable; Fie, priuacy? Fie.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: There was (mine Hoſt) an old-fat-woman euen now with me, but ſhe's gone.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Pray you Sir, was't not the Wiſe-woman of Brainford?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I marry was it (Muſſel-ſhell) what would you with her?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My Maſter (Sir) my maſter Slender, ſent to her ſeeing her go thorough the ſtreets, to know (Sir) whether one Nim (Sir) that beguil'd him of a chaine, had the chaine or no▪

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I ſpake with the old woman about it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And what ſayes ſhe, I pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Marry ſhee ſayes, that the very ſame man that beguil'd Maſter Slender of his Chaine, cozon'd him of it.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I would I could haue ſpoken with the Woman her ſelfe, I had other things to haue ſpoken with her too, from him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What are they? let vs know.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I; come, quicke.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I may not conceale them (Sir.)

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Conceale them, or thou di'ſt.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why ſir, they were nothing but about Miſtris Anne Page, to know if it were my Maſter fortune to haue her, or no.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: 'Tis, 'tis his fortune▪

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: To haue her, or no: goe; ſay the woman told me ſo.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.p: May I be bold to ſay ſo Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I Sir: like who more bold.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I thanke your worſhip: I ſhall make my Maſter glad with theſe tydings.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Thou are clearkly; thou art clearkly (Sir Iohn) was there a wiſe woman with thee?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I that there was (mine Hoſt) one that hath taught me more wit, then euer I learn'd before in my life: and I paid nothing for it neither, but was paid for my learning.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Out alas (Sir) cozonage: meere cozonage.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Where be my horſes? ſpeake well of them varletto.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Run away with the cozoners: for ſo ſoone as I came beyond Eaton, they threw mee off, from behinde one of them, in a ſlough of myre; and ſet ſpurres, and away; like three Germane-diuels; three Doctor Fauſtaffes.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: They are gone but to meete the Duke (villaine) doe not ſay they be fled: Germanes are honeſt men.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: Where is mine Hoſt?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: What is the matter Sir?

sp.speaker: Euan:
sp.p:
Haue a care of your entertainments: there is a friend of mine come to Towne, tels mee there is three Cozen-Iermans, that has cozened all the Hoſts of Readius,
of Maidenhead; of Cole-brooke, of horſes and money: I tell you for good will (looke you) you are wiſe, and full of gibes, and vlouting-ſtocks: and 'tis not conuenient you ſhould be cozoned. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Ver'is mine Hoſt de Iarteere?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Here (Maſter Doctor) in perplexitie, and doubtfull delemma.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: I cannot tell vat is dat: but it is tell-a-me, dat you make grand preparation for a Duke de Iamanie: by my trot; der is no Duke that the Court is know, to come▪ I tell you for good will; adieu.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Huy and cry, (villaine) goe: aſſiſt me Knight, I am vndone: fly, run: huy, and cry (villaine) I am vndone.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I would all the world might bee cozond, for I haue beene cozond and beaten too: if it ſhould come to the eare of the Court, how I haue beene transformed; and how my transformation hath beene waſhd, and cudgeld, they would melt mee out of my fat drop by drop, and liquor Fiſhermens-boots with mee: I warrant they would whip mee with their fine wits, till I were as creſt-falne as a dride-peare I neur proſper'd ſince I forſwore my ſelfe at Primero: well, if my winde were but long enough; I would repent; Now? Whence come you?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: From the two parties forſooth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: •• e Diuell take one partie, and his Dam the other: and ſo they ſhall bee both beſtowed; I haue ſuffer'd more for their ſakes; more then the villanous inconſtancy of mans diſpoſition is able to beare.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: And haue not they ſuffer'd? Yes, I warrant; ſpeciouſly one of them; Miſtris Ford (good heart) is beaten blacke and blew, that you cannot ſee a white ſpot about her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
What tell'ſt thou mee of blacke, and blew? I was beaten my ſelfe into all the colours of the Rainebow:
and I was like to be apprehended for the Witch of Braineford, but that my admirable dexteritie of wit, my counterfeiting the action of an old woman deliuer'd mee, the knaue Conſtable had ſet meith' Stocks, ith' common Stocks, for a Witch.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Sir: let me ſpeake with you in your Chamber, you ſhall heare how things goe, and (I warrant) to your content: here is a Letter will ſay ſomewhat: (goodhearts) what a-doe here is to bring you together? Sure, one of you do's not ſerue heauen well, that you are ſo croſſ'd.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Come vp into my Chamber.

div.head: Scoena Sexta.
div.stage: Enter Fenton, Hoſt.

lg.l: Maſter Fenton, talke not to me, my minde is heauy:
I will giue ouer all.
Yet heare me ſpeake; aſſiſt me in my purpoſe,
And (as I am a gentleman) ile giue thee
A hundred pound in gold, more then your loſſe.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: I will heare you (Maſter Fenton) and I will▪ (at the leaſt) keepe your counſell.

lg.l: From time to time, I haue acquainted you
With the deare loue I beare to faire Anne Page,
Who, mutually, hath anſwer'd my affection,
(So farre forth, as her ſelfe might be her chooſer)
Euen to my wiſh; I haue a letter from her
Of ſuch contents, as you will wonder at;
The mirth whereof, ſo larded with my matter,
That neither (ſingly) can be manifeſted
Without the ſhew of both: fat Falſtaffe
Hath a great Scene; the image of the ieſt.
Ile ſhow you here at large (harke good mine Hoſt;)
To night at Hernes-Oke, iuſt 'twixt twelue and one,
Muſt my ſweet Nun preſent the Fairie Queene;
The purpoſe why, is here▪ in which diſguiſe
While other leſts are ſomething ranke on foote,
Her father hath commanded her to ſlip
Away with Slender, and with him, at Eaton
Immediately to Marry; She hatſt conſented▪ Now Sir,
Her Mother, (euen ſtrong againſt that match
And firme for Doctor Caius) hath appointed
That he ſhall likewiſe ſhuffle her away,
While other ſports are tasking of their mindes,
And at the Deanry, where a Prieſt attends
Strait marry her: to this her Mothers plot
She (ſeemingly obedient) likewiſe hath
Made promiſe to the Doctor; Now, thus it reſts,
Her Father meanes ſhe ſhall be all in white;
And in that habit, when Slender ſees his time
To take her by the hand, and bid her goe.
She ſhall go with him; her Mother hath intended
(The better to deuote her to the Doctor;
For they muſt all be mask'd, and vizarded)
That quaint in greene, ſhe ſhall be looſe en-roab'd,
With Ribonds pendant, flaring'bout her head;
And when the Doctor ſpies his vantage ripe,
To pinch her by the hand, and on that token,
The maid hath giuen conſent to go with him.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Which meanes ſhe to deceiue? Father, or Mother.

lg.l: Both (my good Hoſt) to go along with me:
And heere it reſts, that you'l procure the Vicar
To ſtay for me at Church, 'twixt twelue, and one,
And in the lawfull name of marrying,
To giue our hearts vnited ceremony.
Well, husband your deuice; Ile to the Vicar,
Bring you the Maid, you ſhall not lacke a Prieſt.
So ſhall I euermore be bound to thee;
Beſides, ile make a preſent recompence.

div.head: Scoena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Falſtaffe, Quickly, and Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pre'thee no more pratling; goe, ile hold, this is the third time: I hope good lucke lies in odde numbers: Away, go, they ſay there is Diuinity in odde Numbers, either in natiuity, chance, or death: away.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Ile prouide you a chaine, and ile do what I can to get 〈◊〉 a paire of hornes.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Away I ſay, time weares, hold vp your head and mince. How now Maſter Broome? Maſter Broome, the matter will be knowne to night, or neuer. Bee you in the Parke about midnight, at Hernes-Oake, and you ſhall ſee wonders.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Went you not to her yeſterday (Sir) as you told me you had appointed?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I went to her (Maſter Broome) as you ſee, like a poore-old-man, but I came from her (Maſter Broome) like a poore-old-woman; that ſame knaue (Ford her husband) hath the fineſt mad diuell of iealouſie in him (Maſter Broome) that euer gouern'd Frenſie. I will tell you, he beate me greeuouſly, in the ſhape of a woman: (for in the ſhape of Man (Maſter Broome) I feare not Goliah with a Weauers beame, becauſe I know alſo, life is a Shuttle) I am in haſt, go along with mee, ile tell you all (Maſter Broome:) ſince I pluckt Geeſe, plaide Trewant, and whip • Top, I knew not what'twas to be beaten, till lately-Follow me, ile tell you ſtrange things of this knaue Ford, on whom to night I will be reuenged, and I will deliuer his wife into your hand. Follow, ſtrange things in hand (Maſter Broome) follow.

div.head: Scena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Page, Shallow, Slender.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Come, come: wee'll couch i'th Caſtle-ditch, till wee ſee the light of our Fairies. Remember ſonne Slender, my

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I forſoothe, I haue ſpoke with her, and wee haue a nay-word, how to know one another. I come to her in white, and cry Mum; ſhe cries Budget, and by that we know one another.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: That's good too: But what needes either your Mum, or her Budget? The white will decipher her well enough. It hath ſtrooke ten a▪ clocke.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: The night is darke, Light and Spirits will become it well: Heauen proſper our ſport. No man meanes euill but the deuill, and we ſhall know him by his hornes. Lets away: follow me.

div.head: Scoena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Miſ. Page, Miſ. Ford, Caius.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: Maſter Doctor, my daughter is in green, when you ſee your time, take her by the hand, away with her to the Deanerie, and diſpatch it quickly; goe before into the Parke; we two muſt goe together.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: I know vat I haue to do, adieu.

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: Fare you well (Sir:) my husband will not reioyce ſo much at the abuſe of Falſtaffe, as he will chafe at the Doctors marrying my daughter; But 'tis no matter; better a little chiding, then a great deale of heartbreake.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p:
Where is Nan now? and her troope of Fairies?
and the Welch-deuill Herne?

sp.speaker: Miſt. Page.
sp.p: They are couch'd in a pit hard by Hernes Oake, with obſcur'd Lights; which at the very inſtant of Falſtaffes and our meeting, they will at once diſplay to the night.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: That cannot chooſe but amaze him.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: If he be not amaz'd, he will be mock'd; If he be amaz'd, he will euery way be mock'd.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Wee'll betray him finely.

lg.l: Againſt ſuch Lewdſters, and their lechery,
Thoſe that betray them, do no treachery.

sp.speaker: Mi. Ford.
sp.p: The houre drawes-on; to the Oake, to the Oake.

div.head: Scoena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Euans and Fairies.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: Trib, trib Fairies; Come, and remember your parts: be pold (I pray you) follow me into the pit, and when I giue the watch-'ords, do as I pid you; Come, come trib, trib.

div.head: Scoena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Falſtaffe, Miſtris Page, Miſtris Ford, Euans, Anne Page, Fairies, Page, Ford, Quickly, Slender, Fenton, Caius, Piſtoll.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
The Windſor-bell hath ſtroke twelue: the Minute drawes on: Now the hot-bloodied▪ Gods aſſiſt mee; Remember loue, thou was't a Bull for thy Europa, Loue ſet on thy hornes. O powerfull Loue, that in ſome reſpects makes a Beaſt a Man: in ſome other, a Man a beaſt. You were alſo (Iupiter) a Swan, for the loue of Leda: O omnipotent Loue, how nere the God drew to the complexion
of a Gooſe: a fault done firſt in the forme of a beaſt, (O Ioue, a beaſtly fault:) and then another fault, in the ſemblance of a Fowle, thinke on't (Ioue) a fowlefault. When Gods haue hot backes, what ſhall poore men doe? For me, I am heere a Windſor Stagge, and the fatteſt (I thinke) i'th Forreſt. Send me a coole rut-time (Ioue) or who can blame mee to piſſe my Tallow? Who comes heere my Doe?

lg.l: Sir Iohn? Art thou there (my Deere?)
My male-Deere?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: My Doe, with the blacke Scut? Let the skie raine Potatoes: let it thunder, to the tune of Greeneſleeues, haile-kiſſing Comfit, and ſnow Eringoes; Let there come a tempeſt of prouocation, I will ſhelter mee heere.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford.
sp.p: Miſtris Page is come with me (ſweet heart.)

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Diuide me like a brid'd-Bucke, each a Haunch: I will keepe my ſides to my ſelfe, my ſhoulders for the fellow of this walke; and my hornes I bequeath your husband. Am I a Woodman, ha? Speake I like Herne the Hunter? Why, now is Cupid a child of conſcience, he makes reſtitution. As I am a true ſpirit, welcome.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Alas, what noiſe?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Heauen forgiue-our ſinnes.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What ſhould this be?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: M. Page. Away, away.

lg.l: I thinke the diuell will not haue me damn'd,
Leſt the oyle that's in me ſhould ſet hell on fire;
He would neuer elſe croſſe me thus.

div.stage: Enter Eairies.

lg.l: Fairies blacke, gray, greene, and white,
You Moone-ſhine reuellers, and ſhades of night.
You Orphan heires of fixed deſtiny,
Attend your office, and your quality.
Crier Hob-goblyn, make the Fairy Oyes.
Elues, liſt your names: Silence you aiery toyes.
Cricket, to Windſore-chimnies ſhalt thou leape;
Where fires thou find'ſt vnrak'd, and hearths vnſwept,
There pinch the Maids as blew as Bill-berry,
Our radiant Queene, hates Sluttery.
They are Fairies, he that ſpeaks to them ſhall die,
Ile winke, and couch: No man their workes muſt eie.
Wher's Bede? Go you, and where you finde a maid
That ere ſhe ſleepe has thrice her prayers ſaid,
Raiſe vp the Organs of her fantaſie,
Sleepe ſhe as ſound as careleſſe infancie,
But thoſe as ſleepe, and thinke not on their ſins,
Pinch them armes, legs, backes, ſhoulders, ſides, and ſhins.
About, about:
Search Windſor Caſtle (Elues) within, and out:
Strew good lucke (Ouphes) on euery ſacred roome,
That it may ſtand till the perpetuall doome,
In ſtate as wholſome, as in ſtate 'tis fit,
Worthy the Owner, and the Owner it.
The ſeuerall Chaires of Order, looke you ſcowre
With iuyce of Balme; and euery precious flower,
Each faire Inſtalment, Coate, and ſeu'rall Creſt,
With loyall Blazon, euermore be bleſt.
And Nightly-meadow-Fairies, looke you ſing
Like to the Garters-Compaſſe, in a ring,
Th'expreſſure that it beares: Greene let it be,
Mote fertile-freſh then all the Field to ſee;
And, Hony Soit Qui Mal-y-Pence, write
In Emrold ruffes, Flowres purple, blew; and white,
Like Saphire-pearle, and rich embroidery,
Buckled below faire Knight-hoods bending knee;
Fairies vſe Flowres for their characterie:
Away, diſperſe: But till 'tis one a clocke,
Our Dance of Cuſtome, round about the Oke
Of Herne the Hunter, let vs not forget.
Pray you locke hand in hand: your ſelues in order ſet.
And twenty glo-wormes ſhall our Lanthornes bee
To guide our Meaſure round about the Tree.
But ſtay, I ſmell a man of middle earth.
Heauens defend me from that Welſh Fairy,
Leſt he transforme me to a peece of Cheeſe.

sp.speaker: Piſtoll.
sp.p: Vilde worme, thou waſt ore-look'd euen in thy birth.

lg.l: With Triall-fire touch me his finger end;
If he be chaſte, the flame will backe deſcend
And turne him to no paine: but if he ſtart,
It is the fleſh of a corrupted hart.

sp.speaker: Piſt.
sp.p: A triall, come.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Come: will this wood take fire?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh.

lg.l: Corrupt, corrupt, and tainted in deſire.
About him (Fairies) ſing a ſcornfull rime,
And as you trip, ſtill pinch him to your time.

lg.head: The Song.
lg.l: Fie on ſinnefull phantaſie: Fie on Luſt, and Luxirie.
Luſt is but a bloudy fire, kindled with vnchaſte deſire,
Fed in heart whoſe flames aſpire,
As thoughts do blow them higher and higher:
Pinch him (Fairies) mutuall: Pinch him for his villanie.
Pinch him, and burne him, and turne him about,
Till Candles, and Star-light, and Moone-ſhine be out.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Nay doe not flye, I thinke wee haue watcht you now; Will none but Hern •
the Hunter ſerue your turne?

lg.l: I pray you come, hold vp the ieſt no higher.
Now (good Sir Iohn) how like you Windſor wiues?
See you theſe husband? Do not theſe faire yoakes
Become the Forreſt better then the Towne?

sp.speaker: Ford.

lg.l: Now Sir, who's a Cuckold now?
Maſter Broome, Falſtaffes a Knaue, a Cuckoldy knaue,
Heere are his hornes Maſter Broome;

sp.p: And Maſter Broome, he hath enioyed nothing of Fords, but his Buck-basket, his cudgell, and twenty pounds of money, which muſt be paid to Maſter Broome, his horſes are arreſted for it, Maſter Broome.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Sir Iohn, wee haue had ill lucke: wee could neuer meete: I will neuer take you for my Loue againe, but I will alwayes count you my Deere.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I doe begin to perceiue that I am made an Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I, and an Oxe too; both the proofes are extant.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: And theſe are not Fairies;

I was three or foure times in the thought they were not Fairies, and yet the guiltineſſe of my minde, the ſodaine ſurprize of my powers, droue the groſſeneſſe of the foppery into a receiu'd beleefe, in deſpight of the teeth of all rime and reaſon, that they were Fairies. See now how wit may bee made a Iacke-a-Lent, when 'tis vpon ill imployment.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Falſtaffe, ſerue Got, and leaue your deſires, and Fairies will not pinſe you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well ſaid Fairy Hugh:

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: And leaue you your iealouzies too, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I will neuer miſtruſt my wife againe, till thou art able to woo her in good Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Haue I laid my braine in the Sun, and dri'de it, that it wants matter to preuent ſo groſſe ore-reaching as this? Am I ridden with a Welch Goate too? Shall I haue a Coxcombe of Frize? Tis time I were choak'd with a peece of toaſted Cheeſe.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Seeſe is not good to giue putter; your belly is all putter.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Seeſe, and Putter? Haue I liu'd to ſtand at the taunt of one that makes Fritters of Engliſh? This is enough
to be the decay of luſt and late-walking through the Realme.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Why Sir Iohn, doe you thinke though wee would haue thruſt vertue out of our hearts by the head and ſhoulders, and haue giuen our ſelues without ſcruple to hell, that euer the deuill could haue made you our delight?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: What, a hodge-pudding? A bag of flax?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: A puftman?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Old, cold, wither'd, and of intollerable entrailes?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And one that is ſlanderous as Sathan?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: And as poore as Iob?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And as wicked as his wife?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: And giuen to Fornications, and to Tauernes, and Sacke, and Wine, and Metheglins, and to drinkings and ſwearings, and ſtarings? Pribles and prables?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, I am your Theame: you haue the ſtart of me, I am deiected: I am not able to anſwer the Welch Flannell, Ignorance it ſelfe is plummet ore me, vſe mee as you will.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Marry Sir, wee'l bring you to Windſor to one Maſter Broome, that you haue cozon'd of money, to whom you ſhould haue bin a Pander: ouer and aboue that you haue ſuffer'd, I thinke, to repay that money will be a biting affliction.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yet be cheerefull Knight: thou ſhalt eat a poſſet to night at my houſe, where I will deſire thee to laugh at my wife, that now laughes at thee: Tell her Maſter Slender hath married her daughter.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Ford▪
sp.p: Doctors doubt that;
If Anne Page be my daughter, ſhe is (by this) Doctour Caius wife.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Whoa hoe, hoe, Father Page,

lg.l: Sonne? How now Sonne.
Haue you diſpatch'd?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Diſpatch'd? Ile make the beſt in'Gloſterſhire know on't: would I were hang'd la, elſe.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Of what ſonne?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I came yonder at Eaton to marry Miſtris Anne Page, and ſhe's a great lubberly boy. If it had not beene i'th Church, I would haue ſwing'd him, or hee ſhould haue ſwing'd me. If I did not thinke it had beene Anne Page, would I might neuer ſtirre, and 'tis a Poſt-maſters Boy.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Vpon my life then, you tooke the wrong.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: What neede you tell me that? I thinke ſo, when I tooke a Boy for a Girle: If I had beene maried to him, for all hee was in womans apparrell) I would not haue had him.

lg.l: Why this is your owne folly,
Did not I tell you how you ſhould know my daughter, By her garments?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I went to her in greene, and cried Mum, and ſhe cride budget, as Anne and I had appointed, and yet it was not Anne, but a Poſt-maſters boy.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Good George be not angry, I knew of your purpoſe: turn'd my daughter in white, and indeede ſhee is now with the Doctor at the Denerie, and there married.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Ver is Miſtris Page: by gar I am cozoned, I ha married oon Garſoon, a boy; oon peſant, by gar. A boy, it is not An Page, by gar, I am cozened.

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Why? did you take her in white?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: I bee gar, and 'tis a boy; be gar Ile raiſe all Windſor.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: This is ſtrange: Who hath got the right Anne?

lg.l: My heart miſgiues me, here comes Maſter Fenton▪
How now Maſter Fenton?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Pardon good father, good my mother pardon

lg.l: Now Miſtris;
How chance you went not with Maſter Slender?

sp.speaker: Miſ. Page.
sp.p: Why went you not with Maſter Doctor, maid?

lg.l: You do amaze her: heare the truth of it.
You would haue married her moſt ſhamefully,
Where there was no proportion held in loue:
The truth is, ſhe and I (long ſince contracted)
Are now ſo ſure that nothing can diſſolue vs,
Th'offence is holy, that ſhe hath committed,
And this deceit looſes the name of craft,
Of diſobedience, or vnduteous title,
Since therein ſhe doth euitate and ſhun
A thouſand irreligious curſed houres
Which forced marriage would haue brought vpon her.
Stand not amaz'd, here is no remedie:
In Loue, the heauens themſelues do guide the ſtate,
Money buyes Lands, and wiues are ſold by fate.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I am glad, though you haue tane a ſpecial ſtand to ſtrike 〈◊〉 that your Arrow hath glanc'd.

lg.l: Well, what remedy? Fenton, heauen giue thee ioy,
What cannot bee eſchew'd, muſt be embrac'd.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: When night-dogges run, all ſorts of Deere are chac'd.

lg.l: Well, I will muſe no further: Maſter Fenton,
Heauen giue you many, many merry dayes:
Good husband, let vs euery one go home,
And laugh this ſport ore by a Countrie fire,
Sir Iohn and all.
Let it be ſo (Sir Iohn:)
To Maſter Broome, you yet ſhall hold your word,
For he, to night, ſhall lye with Miſtris Ford.
